title: Why is it that we calm down when we take a deep breath, hold it for a few seconds and exhale?
text: When you take a deep breath, it's like giving your body a little hug from the inside! When you breathe in deeply, your body gets more air and oxygen, which helps your brain feel better. Holding your breath for a few seconds is like pausing a movie so you can enjoy a quiet moment. Then, when you breathe out slowly, it's like letting go of all the yucky feelings, like being upset or scared. This makes your heart feel calmer and helps you relax, just like when you cuddle with a favorite toy or blanket. So, deep breathing helps you feel calm and happy!

title: Why there was a 'leap second' added to the end of 2016?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big clock that helps us know what time it is, like the one you see in a classroom. This clock usually ticks every second, but sometimes, the Earth doesn't spin exactly in sync with those ticks. It's like if you were playing a game, but you were a little too fast or a little too slow. So, to help keep everything lined up, scientists decided to add a tiny extra second, called a 'leap second,' at the end of the year. In 2016, they added this extra second because the Earth's spinning was a bit off, and they wanted to make sure our clocks matched how long a day really is. So, at the end of 2016, when everyone was counting down to midnight, there was one extra second added, making New Year's Eve last just a little bit longer!

title: How is property in outer space valued? If the earth colonized Mars what government/organisation would technically own it
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons. If you draw a picture and say, "This is mine," it’s yours, right? But what if you want to claim a crayon that’s floating in the sky? That gets tricky! In outer space, there are special rules made by countries that say no one can own a planet like Mars. It’s like saying you can’t claim a whole box of crayons that doesn’t belong to anyone. If people from Earth went to Mars and started living there, then the question of who owns it would depend on what rules those people decided to follow. Maybe they would make a new group or organization to decide what to do, kind of like a class deciding who gets to use the crayons. So, right now, no one really owns space like you own your toys, and if we go to Mars, we’d have to figure it out together!

title: Why does 1080p on a 4k TV look better than 1080p on a 1080p TV?
text: Okay, imagine you have two different kinds of picture frames. One frame is really big, like a giant window, and the other is just a regular size. If you put a pretty drawing in both frames, the big frame can make the drawing look even nicer because it has more space to show it off. A 4K TV is like that big frame; it has lots of tiny dots (called pixels) that can make pictures look super clear and colorful. So, when you watch a 1080p video (which is like a drawing that’s not as big) on a 4K TV, it uses all those extra dots to make the picture look better and smoother than if you watched it on a regular 1080p TV, which has fewer dots. So, even though the video is the same, the 4K TV just has a special way of showing it that makes it look nicer!

title: How do you claim undiscovered land?
text: Claiming undiscovered land means saying that a piece of land belongs to you, but it’s a little tricky. Imagine you find a big, empty island that nobody lives on. To claim it, you would usually need to do a few things: first, you have to make sure that no one else is using it or saying it belongs to them. Then, you would need to tell people you found it and want it to be yours, kind of like putting a flag on it or writing your name on a piece of paper and showing it to others. But in real life, most land has already been claimed by countries or people, so finding truly undiscovered land is super rare! Plus, there are rules and laws that countries follow, so it’s not just about saying it’s yours.

title: Why does lights make a "blinking" effect when looking at them from far away?
text: When you look at a light from far away, it can sometimes look like it's blinking or twinkling. This happens because the air between you and the light is kind of like a wiggly blanket. Sometimes, the air is hot and other times it's cooler, and these different temperatures make the light bend a little bit as it travels to your eyes. When the light bends, it can look like it's changing or blinking, especially if there are tiny bits of dust or other stuff in the air too. So, it’s not really the light blinking, it’s just how the air is making it look!

title: Why do we fail to do realistic human CGI (like in SW Rouge One) yet we do it so great on non-human beings (like in Warcraft)?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a really cool toy that looks like a robot and it moves around and talks, and everyone thinks it’s super awesome. Now, when you try to make a toy that looks like a real person, it gets a little tricky. This is because our brains are really good at noticing tiny details, like how a person’s skin looks or how they smile. In movies like "Rogue One," they made a character look like a real person, but it didn’t quite look real enough for everyone to believe it was real. With non-human characters like orcs in "Warcraft," they can be a little more cartoonish and less detailed, so it’s easier to make them look amazing and magical without our brains getting confused. So, it’s harder to make real people look perfect because we expect them to look super real, while non-human characters can be a bit more fun and imaginative!

title: How are pop-up and generally annoying web ads viable?
text: Pop-up ads and annoying web ads are like those loud toys that make noise when you press a button. They grab your attention because they are big and noisy, and that's what the people who make these ads want! They want you to see their stuff, like toys or games, so you might want to buy them. Even if you don't like them and try to close them, some people will still click on them by accident, or just out of curiosity. That makes the companies that make the ads happy because they get money every time someone clicks on their ad, even if it’s just one person. So, even though most people find them annoying, they still help companies make money, and that’s why they keep making them!

title: why does it hurt when you swallow a beverage "wrong" ?
text: When you swallow a drink "wrong," it means some of the liquid goes down the wrong tube instead of the right one. You have two tubes in your throat: one for food and drinks (the esophagus) and one for air (the trachea). If you accidentally send your drink into the tube for air, it can make you cough and feel uncomfortable because your body is trying to get the drink out of the wrong place. It can also hurt a little because your throat gets irritated when the drink goes where it shouldn't. It's like if you accidentally spill water on your skin—it feels a bit weird and you want to wipe it off!

title: Why do the instructions on pasta call for you to measure out water?
text: Okay, so when you cook pasta, you need to use water to make it soft and yummy. Measuring the water is important because if you don’t use enough, the pasta might stick together, and if you use too much, it can take a long time to cook and might get too watery. The right amount helps the pasta cook evenly and taste just right, kind of like how you need the right amount of ingredients to bake a cake! So, measuring helps make sure your pasta turns out delicious!

title: Why would a drug dealer lace their product with carfentanil, which is causing so many OD deaths? Aren't they reducing their own customer base?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really yummy cake that everyone likes, but you want to make it even tastier so more people will come to eat it. A drug dealer might think that adding something super strong like carfentanil to their product will make it feel more powerful or fun for people who use it, kind of like adding extra sprinkles or frosting. But carfentanil is super dangerous—it's used to help big animals like elephants, not people! So, when people take it, they might get really sick or even die. The dealer might not care about that because they just want to sell more quickly and make money, even if it means some people won't come back. It’s really risky and not good for anyone, but they might not think about the bad things that could happen.

title: Why is ventilation needed for indoor or underground rooms?
text: Ventilation is like giving fresh air to a room, just like how opening a window lets in a nice breeze. When we stay in a room, we breathe out air that can get stuffy and not very good for us after a while. In underground rooms or places with no windows, the air can feel heavy and stale because there’s no fresh air coming in. Ventilation helps by bringing in new air and letting out the old air, which makes it easier for us to breathe and keeps the room from smelling bad. It’s kind of like when you blow up a balloon; if you don’t let the air out, it can pop! So, we need ventilation to keep our indoor spaces safe and comfy!

title: Why is ♡ considered a heart when a heart doesn't look like that? Also, how does it relate to love?
text: Okay, imagine a heart shape like the one you see in drawings, the one that looks like a pointy bottom and a round top. A long time ago, people started using that shape to show feelings, especially love, because it felt warm and nice, just like how love feels! Even though a real heart in our bodies looks more like a squishy, lumpy thing, the drawing is easier to make and remember. So, when we see that heart shape (♡), we think of happy feelings and love, like when you hug your mom or play with your friends. It’s a special symbol that helps us share those nice feelings, even if it doesn’t look exactly like our hearts!

title: Why do vitamin C tablets say stuff like 800% your daily value? Does that mean the rest gets wasted?
text: Okay, so imagine your body is like a sponge that can soak up a certain amount of water, which is the vitamins you need. When you see something that says "800% your daily value" for vitamin C, it means that if you take that tablet, it has way more vitamin C than your body really needs in one day—like filling a sponge with way more water than it can hold! Your body can only use what it needs, and the extra part that it doesn’t need just gets thrown away when you go to the bathroom, kind of like spilling water out of the sponge. So, yes, the extra gets wasted, but it’s okay because your body is really good at taking what it needs and letting go of the rest!

title: Why were slaves treated so badly?
text: A long time ago, some people thought it was okay to own other people and make them work really hard without paying them or treating them nicely. They believed they were better than the slaves, which was very wrong. The people who owned slaves wanted to make money and didn't care about the feelings or lives of the slaves. So, they made them work in terrible conditions, didn't let them rest, and were very mean to them. This was very unfair and hurtful, and many people now understand that everyone should be treated with kindness and respect, no matter what.

title: Why is it so difficult to smell ourselves?
text: It's hard to smell ourselves because our noses get used to our own smells like a favorite blanket. When you wear the blanket all the time, you don’t really notice how it feels anymore. Our brains are super smart and pay more attention to new smells that we haven’t smelled before, so they kind of ignore our own smells after a while. It's like when you eat a lot of your favorite food; after a bit, it doesn't taste as special anymore. That’s why when you smell something different, like a flower or a cookie, it stands out more than your own smell!

title: Why do singers (*cough* Mariah Carey *cough*) have such a tough time when an earpiece or monitor isn't working, but the dancers are able to keep pace without anything?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing a game where you have to sing a song while jumping around. If you can hear the song really well in your ears, it's like having a special friend helping you stay on beat and sing the right notes. But if that friend goes away and you can't hear the song, it can be super hard to know when to sing or what notes to hit, and you might get confused! Singers like Mariah Carey need to hear the music perfectly to sing their best. Dancers, on the other hand, can watch the beat of the music with their eyes and feel the rhythm in their bodies, so they can keep moving even if they can't hear it perfectly. It's like when you're dancing at a party and you can see everyone else dancing, so you know when to jump and spin even if the music is a bit quiet!

title: What is happening when one commercial is interrupted by/for another?
text: When one commercial is interrupted by another, it's like when you're watching a fun cartoon, and suddenly the screen changes to a different show for a little bit. This happens because the people who make the shows want to tell you about other fun things you might want to buy or try, like toys or snacks. So, they put short ads in between the shows to grab your attention and make sure you see what they're selling. It's kind of like a surprise break from your show to learn about something new!

title: Why do comedians repeat phrases of their jokes/stories every so often while performing on stage?
text: Comedians repeat phrases in their jokes or stories to help people remember them and to make them even funnier! It's like when you hear a catchy song on the radio, and you start singing along because you remember the words. By saying a funny phrase again, it builds excitement and makes everyone laugh even more. It also helps the audience know what's coming next, like a fun game where you guess what happens! So, repeating things is a way to keep everyone happy and having a great time.

title: Why do newspapers often have random sentences where a l l t h e w o r d s a r e w r i t t e n l i k e t h i s?
text: Sometimes, newspapers or websites will show words stretched out like this to make it look interesting or to grab your attention. It can be used for fun or to highlight something important. But usually, it’s not how we normally write. It’s like when you draw a funny picture to make people laugh!

title: I just read that it takes 26 hours for New Year to pass all time zones, how can that happen?
text: Okay, so imagine the Earth is like a big round ball, and it's spinning around like a top. When it's New Year in one place, like in Australia, they start celebrating, but the places on the other side of the world, like in America, are still in the old year because it's still daytime there. The Earth is divided into different time zones, which are like slices of the ball, and each slice has a different time. When one part of the world hits midnight and celebrates the New Year, it takes a long time for all the other parts to catch up because the Earth keeps spinning. So, it takes about 26 hours for the New Year to go all around the world, from the first place that celebrates to the last place!

title: How does Spotify and Apple Music pay artists?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big cookie jar and everyone loves cookies. When you eat a cookie, you put a little bit of money in the jar to share with the person who made the cookies. Spotify and Apple Music are like big cookie jars filled with lots of songs instead of cookies. When you listen to a song, it's like taking a cookie from the jar. The money you pay for the music goes into the jar, and then the people who made the songs, like singers and musicians, get some of that money. They don't get all of it, just a piece, because the music jar has to pay for other things too, like running the app and keeping the lights on. So, the more people listen to a song, the more money the artist can get from that jar!

title: Why is it when we chew/swallow food or drink, we don't gag but if we have to have a medical procedure that involves something going down our airway or dentist, we don't gag?
text: When we eat or drink, our body knows how to help us swallow without choking or gagging because it’s something we do all the time. We chew our food into small pieces, and our throat knows how to push it down to our stomach. But when we have to go to the doctor or the dentist, sometimes they use special tools or tubes that go into our mouth or throat. Even though it feels funny, our brains are focused on what the doctor is doing, so they can help us, and we don’t think about gagging as much. Plus, doctors and dentists are trained to do it quickly and carefully, so it’s not the same as eating, where we have to think about every bite.

title: how does someone like bill gates keep all of his money?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big jar of candy, and you want to keep it safe so you can enjoy it later. Bill Gates has a lot of money, like a giant jar of candy, and he keeps it safe by doing a few things. First, he has smart people who help him decide where to put his money, like in banks or businesses that can grow and make more money over time. He also doesn’t spend all his money at once; he saves some and spends some wisely. Plus, he gives some away to help others, like sharing candy with friends, which makes him feel good. So, by being careful and making good choices, he keeps his money safe and even makes it grow!

title: Why are the atomic numbers of elements unique?
text: Okay, imagine every element is like a different type of toy in a big toy box. The atomic number is like a special sticker on each toy that tells you which toy it is. Each sticker has a different number, and that number shows how many tiny building blocks, called protons, are inside the toy. No two toys (or elements) have the same number of building blocks, so their stickers are always unique. This is why the atomic numbers are special and help us know exactly what each element is!

title: What is the point of Gerber Life? How does taking a life insurance policy out on your baby give them a good financial start?
text: Okay, imagine you have a little baby, and you want to help them when they grow up. Gerber Life is like a special money box you can get for your baby. You pay a little bit of money every month, and if something really bad happens and your baby isn't around anymore, Gerber Life gives you a big pile of money. But here's the cool part: when your baby grows up, they can also use that money for things like going to college or buying their first house. So, it's like planting a money seed that can grow into a big tree of money for the future, helping your baby have a better start when they are older!

title: How can the heart not tire out?
text: The heart is like a little pump that helps move blood all around your body, kind of like how a toy car needs batteries to keep going. It doesn’t get tired because it has its own special way of resting and working at the same time. When you’re not moving around much, like when you're sitting or sleeping, the heart beats slower, and that helps it take a little break. Plus, it’s made of special muscles that are really good at working hard without getting tired easily, sort of like how some superheroes can keep running without stopping! So, even though it works a lot, the heart has ways to keep going strong and not get worn out.

title: How does overuse of antibiotics actually lead to antibiotic resistant bacteria?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons with lots of different colors, and you really like to use the red crayon all the time. If you only use the red crayon and never use the others, one day you might find that the red crayon is all worn down and doesn’t work anymore. Antibiotics are like those crayons; they help us fight off bad germs that make us sick. But if we use antibiotics too much, the germs can learn how to survive, like a crayon that gets stronger and doesn’t break easily. When we use antibiotics a lot, some of the bad germs can change so they don't get hurt by the antibiotics anymore. These strong germs are called antibiotic-resistant bacteria, and they can make us sick again because the medicine we used before doesn’t work against them. So, it's important to only use antibiotics when we really need them, just like it’s better to use all the crayons in the box instead of just one!

title: Why can't devices (phones, laptops, etc) make our headphones noise-cancelling?
text: Okay, so imagine your headphones are like a superhero that can block out loud sounds, like a big, scary monster! But to be a super-good superhero, they need to be specially made with tiny parts inside that help them listen to the noise around you and then make a special sound to cancel it out, kind of like how you might cover your ears when someone is yelling. Your phone or laptop is like a friend who can tell you what’s happening, but they can’t actually put on a superhero cape and do the job for the headphones. So, even though your devices are smart, they can’t turn regular headphones into noise-cancelling ones because they don’t have the special parts that can help block out those loud noises. It’s like trying to make a regular toy car go super fast without changing it into a race car!

title: How to type Korean?
text: To type in Korean, you need to change the language on your computer or phone. It's like picking a different set of crayons to use! First, go to the settings on your device and look for the "language" or "keyboard" option. Then, add Korean as a new language. Once it's added, you can switch between your regular letters and Korean letters by pressing a special key, usually the spacebar or a button that says "language." Now, when you type, you'll see the cool Korean letters instead of your usual ones! Just remember that Korean letters are called Hangul, and they look like little blocks made of different shapes. Have fun typing!

title: why is wearing something bright orange when hunting recommended? Doesn't that defeat the purpose of blending in?
text: Wearing bright orange when hunting is like wearing a big, shiny safety flag! Even though hunters want to blend in with trees and bushes to sneak up on animals, they also need to make sure they can see each other. Since animals like deer can't see bright orange very well, it helps hunters stay safe and not accidentally shoot each other while still trying to be sneaky. So, the bright color keeps everyone safe while they’re out in the woods!

title: Why is Norton hated so much? What makes an antivirus/antimalware program good or bad anyway?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy box, and you want to keep it safe from any bad toys that might break your nice toys. Norton is like a toy guard that tries to find and kick out the bad toys. Some people don’t like Norton because they think it sometimes takes too long to find the bad toys or it can be a little bossy and get in the way when they’re trying to play. A good antivirus program is like a super smart toy guard that finds the bad toys really fast, doesn’t make a mess, and lets you play without bothering you too much. A bad one might be slow, miss some bad toys, or be too annoying. So, people want to find the best toy guard to keep their toys safe and let them have fun!

title: Why is it "bad" to make tea in the microwave vs a kettle?
text: Making tea in the microwave is like trying to warm up your soup with a flashlight instead of using a stove. When you use a kettle, it heats the water evenly and helps the tea leaves release all their yummy flavors. But in the microwave, the water can get hot in some spots and cold in others, making it hard for the tea to taste good. Plus, a kettle is made just for boiling water, so it’s safer and can help you make the best tea!

title: If you were travelling faster than the speed of sound, what would happen if you screamed?
text: Okay, imagine you’re outside and you shout really loud. Your voice travels through the air to reach someone far away, like a friend. When you shout, it moves at a speed called the speed of sound. Now, if you were going even faster than that, like a super-fast rocket, your voice would have trouble keeping up with you! So, if you screamed while flying faster than the speed of sound, the sound of your scream wouldn’t reach anyone behind you because you’d be too far ahead! It’s like if you ran really fast and your friend was trying to catch up to you; they wouldn’t hear you until you slowed down. In fact, if you went really fast, you might even hear a loud boom when you break the sound barrier, kind of like a big clap of thunder!

title: When and how did green generally get associated with positiveness, and red as negativeness?
text: A long time ago, people started using colors to show how they feel or what things mean. Green is often linked to nature, like trees and grass, which makes people feel happy and calm, so it became a color for good things like safety and go-ahead. Red, on the other hand, is the color of fire and danger, like when you see a stop sign or when something is really hot. So, it started to feel more serious or bad, meaning stop or be careful. Over time, we learned to connect these colors with our feelings, and now we often think green is good and red is bad!

title: What's that clicking sound in your ears everytime you yawn?
text: When you yawn, sometimes you hear a clicking sound in your ears. This happens because there’s a tiny tube in your ear called the Eustachian tube that helps balance the air pressure inside your ear. When you yawn, that tube opens up to let air in and out, kind of like a little door. If the air moves quickly or if there's a little change in pressure, it can make a clicking sound. It’s perfectly normal and just means your ears are adjusting!

title: How do Youtubers earn money? I mean, how is revenue generated by simply watching a video. I understand it has something to do with the advertisements, but that is my question, how do ads help Youtubers earn money.
text: Okay, imagine you have a lemonade stand, and you let a friend put up a sign for a toy store right next to your stand. When people come to buy lemonade, they see the toy store sign. If they like the toys and go to buy one, the toy store gives you some money because you helped them by showing their sign to your customers. Youtubers do something similar! When they make videos, YouTube puts ads (which are like those toy store signs) in their videos. When people watch the video and see the ads, sometimes they click on the ads or remember the product later. Because of this, the companies that make the ads pay YouTube some money. YouTube then shares some of that money with the Youtuber, kind of like how the toy store gave you money for showing their sign. So, the more people watch the videos and see the ads, the more money the Youtuber can earn!

title: What is a tensor?
text: Okay! So, imagine you have a box of toys. If you just have one toy, like a teddy bear, that's like a simple number, which we call a "scalar." Now, if you have a toy box that can hold many teddy bears, that's like a list of numbers, which we call a "vector." A tensor is like a really cool, super fancy toy box that can hold many boxes, and even those boxes can hold more toys! So, a tensor can store lots of different numbers in different ways, like a box with lots of compartments, and it helps us understand things like how things move, stretch, or change in the world, kind of like how you can play with your toys in lots of different ways!

title: How does Shutterfly make profit when it gives away so many discounts and free things?
text: Okay, imagine you have a lemonade stand. Sometimes, you give out free samples of your lemonade so people can taste it. When they like it, they might want to buy a whole cup! Shutterfly is kind of like that. They let people try their things for free or give big discounts to attract more customers. Once people see how great the photos, cards, or gifts are, they end up buying even more stuff, and that's how Shutterfly makes money! Plus, when they have lots of customers, they can buy materials in big amounts, which helps them save money, too. So, giving away some free stuff helps them get more people to buy later on!

title: What determines the borders where each timezone starts? If I live on the line which timezone do I follow?
text: So, think of the Earth like a big orange that's been cut into slices. Each slice is a different timezone, which tells us what time it is in that part of the world. The borders for these timezones are mostly made so that they follow lines of longitude, which go from the North Pole to the South Pole. Sometimes, these lines bend and curve to fit around countries or big places, so they don't cut through them in a strange way. Now, if you live right on the line where two timezones meet, it's usually up to you to decide which timezone you want to follow! But most people pick the one where their house is or the one that matches the time at school or work. It's like choosing which side of the playground to play on!

title: Why do non-fighters collapse when they get elbowed in the head, but MMA fighters can take it with the punches so to speak?
text: Okay, imagine you have a balloon. If you tap a regular balloon gently, it might just bounce a little, but if you poke it really hard, it can pop! Now, think of non-fighters as regular balloons. When they get hit in the head, it's like a strong poke, and they might fall down because their heads aren't used to that kind of bump. But MMA fighters are like special balloons that are made to be tougher. They train a lot to get their bodies and heads strong, so when they get hit, their brains are more used to it, and they know how to stay on their feet. So, while a regular balloon might pop easily, the special balloon can handle a lot more before it goes down!

title: Why is there a separate security code on credit cards? If the three extra digits make it that much more secure, why not just make the number three digits longer?
text: Okay, imagine your credit card is like a treasure map that shows where to find your pirate treasure, and the big number on the front is like the big “X” that marks the spot. Now, the three extra digits on the back, called the security code, are like a secret password that only you and the bank know. If someone steals your treasure map, they still can’t get to your treasure without that secret password! If they just made the big number longer, it would still be like having a longer map that someone could still read. The extra three digits make it harder for sneaky pirates to use your treasure map because they need both the map (the big number) and the secret password (the security code) to get to your treasure. So, it's like having two layers of protection instead of just one!

title: How do rebreathers work?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special backpack that helps you breathe underwater, kind of like a fish! Normally, when we breathe, we take in fresh air and then let out used air that has a lot of carbon dioxide, which is like the yucky stuff our bodies don’t want. A rebreather is like a magic backpack that takes the air we breathe out and cleans it so we can use it again. Inside the backpack, there are special things that grab the yucky carbon dioxide and make it safe again. So, when we breathe out, the rebreather cleans it up, and then we can breathe it back in, like recycling air! This way, we can stay underwater longer without running out of air!

title: How do card readers know that a card has a chip?
text: Okay, imagine your card is like a special book, and the chip is a tiny little superhero inside it. When you put your card into a card reader, it's like opening the book. The card reader has its own special powers to talk to the chip. It sends a message to the chip asking, "Hey, are you there?" The chip then wakes up and replies, "Yes, I’m here!" and shares important information, like your name and how much money you have. The card reader can tell if there’s a chip because it can only talk to cards that have that tiny superhero inside them. So, if the card reader hears back from the chip, it knows your card has a chip!

title: Why do we capitalize "Happy New Year"?
text: We capitalize "Happy New Year" because it's a special name for a holiday! Just like we say "Christmas" or "Birthday," we use big letters for these special words to show they're important. So when we say "Happy New Year," we want everyone to know we're talking about a fun celebration, and that's why we make the first letters big!

title: Why do most spiders have many eyes, but poor vision?
text: Okay, imagine if you had a lot of little windows in your house, but they were really dirty and you couldn't see very well through them. That's kind of like how spiders are! Most spiders have many eyes, sometimes up to eight, so they can see all around them, but their eyes don't work like ours. They can’t see colors very well or see far away; they mostly see shapes and movement. This helps them catch bugs because they can notice when something is moving close by, even if they can’t see it clearly. So, having many eyes helps them keep an eye out for dinner, even if they don’t see things super clearly!

title: Why do mobile games suck, even though phones are more powerful than good handheld gaming systems like Gameboy?
text: Okay, imagine your phone is like a big, super fancy box of crayons that can draw lots of different things, and it can even play music and show movies! But when someone makes a mobile game, they often have to think about a lot of things, like making it work on all kinds of phones and making it easy to play with just your fingers. This can mean that the games don’t have as much cool stuff as the big games on special handheld consoles, which have more time and money spent on them to make them super fun. Plus, some mobile games try to make money by asking you to buy extra things while you play, which can make them feel less fun. So, even though your phone is super strong, making a game that everyone loves is harder than it looks!

title: What causes your nasal cavity to sometimes "burn" when there is liquid entering it, but other times it isn't painful?
text: Sometimes when you drink something and it goes up your nose, it can feel like a little burn. This happens because your nose is really sensitive and has a lot of tiny nerves that can feel things. If the liquid is hot, spicy, or has strong flavors, it can make those nerves wake up and say "Ouch!" But if the liquid is cold or just plain water, it doesn't bother your nose as much, so it feels fine. It's like how you can touch a warm cookie and it feels nice, but if you touch a hot stove, it hurts! Your nose just has different feelings for different liquids.

title: How was the canyon diablo meteorite, an object not from earth, used to determine the age of the earth?
text: Okay, so imagine the Earth is like a big, old birthday cake, and scientists want to know how long ago it was made. The Canyon Diablo meteorite is like a crumb from that cake that fell from the sky. It’s really old, and because it comes from space, it hasn't changed like the Earth has. Scientists can look at the tiny bits inside the meteorite, like its rocks and minerals, and use special tools to figure out how old those bits are. They found out that the meteorite is about 4.5 billion years old! Since the Earth and the meteorite were made around the same time, scientists think the Earth is also about 4.5 billion years old. So, by studying this space rock, they learned a lot about the age of our whole planet!

title: Why is the golden ratio common to so many things of different nature?
text: The golden ratio is like a special magic number that helps things look pretty and balanced! Imagine if you had a big pizza and you wanted to cut it into two pieces. If one piece is a little bigger than the other, but not too much, it looks just right! This special way of cutting is what the golden ratio is all about. It shows up in nature, like in flowers, shells, and even the way trees grow because they all want to be balanced and nice to look at. People use it in art and buildings too, like the Parthenon in Greece, because it makes things feel comfortable and beautiful to our eyes. So, the golden ratio is common everywhere because it helps things look good and feel just right!

title: Why are kinder eggs banned in America, but knockoffs aren't?
text: Okay, so Kinder Eggs are these yummy chocolate eggs that have a surprise toy inside. But in America, they are banned because they are not safe. The inside toy can be a choking hazard for little kids, meaning it could get stuck in their throat and make them cough or not be able to breathe. The rules in America try to keep kids safe, so they said "no" to Kinder Eggs. Now, there are knockoffs, or copies, that look like Kinder Eggs but are made differently and are safer, so they can have them. These knockoffs usually have the toy outside or are made in a way that won’t hurt anyone. So, it's like having a toy that’s safe to play with instead of one that could be dangerous!

title: What is the pixel resolution of regular eyesight and what minimum resolution would be needed for VR glasses to match a normal person's vision?
text: Okay, so imagine your eyes are like tiny cameras that take pictures of everything around you. Regular eyesight can see a lot of detail, kind of like having a picture that is really clear and sharp. If we think about this in terms of numbers, regular eyesight can see about 60 pixels in each tiny part of what you see. Now, when we talk about VR glasses, we want them to look just as good as what you see with your own eyes. To do that, the VR glasses should have at least around 2,000 pixels in each tiny part to make everything look super clear and nice, just like how you see in real life. So, if VR glasses have enough pixels, they can make you feel like you’re really there in a fun place!

title: Why is the moment of death always associated with "the light going out from one's eyes"? Does this actually happen or is it just a metaphor?
text: When someone dies, their body stops working, and they don't breathe or move anymore. People often say "the light goes out from their eyes" because it looks like the person is no longer there, like a toy that runs out of batteries and stops working. This doesn't mean there is a real light that disappears; it's just a way to describe how sad and final it feels when someone is gone. So, it's more of a metaphor, which is a fancy word for something that helps us understand feelings or ideas, rather than something that happens literally.

title: How do the police trace a bullet back to its gun?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special toy that makes a really cool design when you draw with it. When you use that toy, it leaves a unique pattern on the paper that nobody else's toy can make exactly the same way. Now, when the police find a bullet, they can look at these tiny marks on the bullet that were made when it was shot out of a gun. Each gun has its own special "drawing" or pattern because of how it was made. The police take pictures of those marks and compare them to pictures of marks made by other guns. If they find a match, it's like finding out which toy made the drawing, so they can figure out which gun shot the bullet!

title: How do life insurers make a profit?
text: Life insurers make a profit by collecting money from people who buy life insurance, which is like a promise that pays money to someone when the person who bought the insurance passes away. They call this money a "premium." The insurance company keeps this money and uses it to pay for claims when needed, but they also invest some of it in things like stocks and bonds to earn more money. They try to make sure that the total money they earn from premiums and investments is more than what they have to pay out for claims, and that way, they can make a profit while still helping people when they need it.

title: Does the question "what was before the Big Bang?" even make sense?
text: Okay, imagine the universe is like a big balloon. When you blow up a balloon, it gets bigger and bigger, right? The Big Bang is like that moment when the balloon starts to be blown up. Before the balloon starts to grow, there’s no balloon at all; it’s just flat. So when we ask "what was before the Big Bang?", it's a bit tricky because there wasn't a "before" like we think of it. Time and space were created when the Big Bang happened, so there wasn’t anything to measure "before" it. It's kind of like asking what’s outside the balloon when it hasn’t even been blown up yet!

title: Why is your reflection upside-down when you look at a spoon on the side that is curved inwards?
text: When you look at a spoon that is curved inwards, it acts like a fun funhouse mirror! The curved shape makes your reflection look different. Imagine the inside of the spoon is like a little hill that pushes your reflection around. When you look at it, the light from your face hits the spoon and bounces back to your eyes in a funny way. This makes your head look like it's upside-down and your feet look like they're on top! So, it’s like the spoon is playing a trick on your eyes because of its shape!

title: Why is ice-cream that's melted then frozen much harder to scoop than fresh ice-cream?
text: When ice cream melts and then freezes again, it gets all icy and hard because the little ice crystals inside it get bigger. Imagine if you had a snowman and it melted a little bit, then froze again. When it freezes back, the snowman becomes more like a big hard block of ice instead of soft, fluffy snow. Fresh ice cream, on the other hand, has tiny ice crystals that make it smooth and creamy, so it's easy to scoop. So, when you try to scoop that re-frozen ice cream, it feels super hard because those big ice crystals are like trying to scoop a rock instead of soft, yummy snow!

title: Why and how do Epsom Salts soothe sore muscles?
text: Epsom salts are like magic little crystals that can help when your muscles feel sore or tired after playing or exercising. When you mix Epsom salts in warm water and then soak in it, your body can absorb some of the special stuff inside the salts, called magnesium. Magnesium helps your muscles relax, kind of like how a cozy blanket helps you feel comfy. It also helps reduce swelling and pain, which is why people feel better after using Epsom salts. So, when you take a warm bath with Epsom salts, it’s like giving your tired muscles a gentle hug that helps them feel better!

title: How do fetishes work/how do you get them?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a favorite toy or a favorite food that makes you really happy. A fetish is kind of like that, but instead of a toy or food, it’s something special that makes some people feel really excited or happy in a different way. Sometimes, when someone sees or thinks about something specific, like a certain type of clothing, or a special part of the body, it can make their heart race or give them a tingly feeling, just like how you feel when you see your favorite ice cream! People can get these feelings from things they see or experience when they're younger, or even just because they really like how something looks or feels. It's just a part of how our brains work, and everyone is a little different!

title: How do we know animals are not as self-conscious as humans?
text: Okay, imagine you have a pet dog and you give it a mirror. When it sees its reflection, it might think there’s another dog there and bark or play. But when you look in a mirror, you know it’s you and you can think about your feelings and what you look like. This is called being self-conscious. Scientists do special tests to see if animals can understand they are looking at themselves and know what that means. Most animals don’t pass these tests like humans do. They don’t seem to think about their feelings or what others think about them in the same deep way we do. So, we think animals aren’t as self-conscious as people, but they can still have their own feelings and thoughts!

title: Bicameral legislatures - how do they work and why do they exist?
text:
Okay! So, imagine you have a big box of crayons and you want to decide which colors to use for your drawing. Now, instead of just one person picking the colors, you ask two of your friends to help you. One friend picks their favorite colors, and the other friend picks some different ones. Together, you all look at the colors and agree on the best ones to use. This way, you get a mix of ideas from both friends, and everyone has a say in what the final picture looks like. 

Bicameral legislatures work kind of like that! A bicameral legislature is a group of people who make the laws for a country, but it has two parts instead of just one. One part is called the "Senate" and the other part is called the "House of Representatives." Each part has different people and different jobs, but they both work together to make sure the laws are fair and good for everyone. This way, just like with the crayons, you get different ideas and opinions, which helps make better decisions!

title: Does being out in the "cold" without a coat actually make you more prone to being sick?
text: No, being in the cold without a coat doesn’t make you sick by itself. It’s like when you go outside to play and get chilly; you might feel uncomfortable, but you won’t catch a cold just from being cold. The reason people get sick is because of germs, which are tiny things that can make you feel bad. When it’s cold outside, more people stay inside together where germs can spread easily. So, it’s not the cold that makes you sick, but being around other people who might have germs. It’s still a good idea to wear a coat when it’s cold to stay warm and comfy!

title: Why does a mere air bubble in the circulatory system prove to be fatal?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big city with lots of roads, and those roads are your blood vessels. The blood is like the cars driving on those roads, bringing things your body needs, like oxygen and food. Now, if a tiny air bubble gets into the blood, it's like if a big rock suddenly blocked one of the roads. The cars can't get past it, so the blood can't flow where it needs to go. If that happens in a really important road, like the one that goes to your heart or brain, it can cause big problems, like the heart or brain not getting the oxygen they need, which can make you very sick or even be very dangerous. So, even a little bubble can cause a lot of trouble!

title: why credit cards are safer than debit cards?
text: Credit cards are often safer than debit cards because they help protect your money better. When you use a credit card, you're borrowing money from the bank to pay for things, instead of using your own money that’s in your bank account like with a debit card. If someone steals your credit card information, you won’t lose your real money right away, and the bank can help you get it back. But if someone steals your debit card information, they can take money straight from your bank account, and it can be harder to get back. Plus, credit cards often have special rules to protect you if something goes wrong, like if you don’t get what you paid for. So, using a credit card can keep your money a little safer!

title: Will sovereign states/countries ever shift from being republics to some different system of government just like how monarchies were slowly phased out? Why or why not?
text: Okay, imagine a big playground where kids can choose how they want to play. Some kids like to make the rules together (that's a republic) and some kids have a special kid who's in charge because their family has always been in charge (that's a monarchy). Over time, some playgrounds decided they didn’t want the special kid in charge anymore and started making rules together instead. Now, sometimes kids in a republic might decide they want to change things too, like having one kid be in charge or even sharing the rules differently. Whether they do that or not depends on what the kids want and how they feel about their games. So, it could happen that some republics change to something else if the people decide they want to, just like how playgrounds can change how they play!

title: Why is salt iodized?
text: Salt is iodized to help people stay healthy! Iodine is a special nutrient that our bodies need to work properly, especially for our brains and thyroid, which is a gland that helps control how our bodies use energy. A long time ago, some people weren't getting enough iodine from their food, which made them sick. So, to fix this, companies started adding iodine to salt, which is something many people use in their cooking. This way, when we eat salt, we're also getting the iodine our bodies need to grow strong and healthy!

title: Why does driving long distances make people tired?
text: Driving long distances makes people tired because it takes a lot of focus and energy. When you drive, you have to pay attention to the road, watch for other cars, and think about where you're going. It's like playing a really long game of "keep your eyes on the ball" where the ball is the road! Your brain is working hard to keep you safe, and your body has to sit still for a long time, which can make you feel sleepy. Plus, if you don’t stop to stretch your legs and take breaks, your muscles can get tired too. Just like when you run around and play all day, driving for a long time can make you feel worn out!

title: In the past, chopping off a hand was a common punishment for thieves. What exactly happens afterwards?
text: Okay, so if someone got their hand chopped off for stealing, it would be really, really painful, like getting a very bad boo-boo. After that, they would have to go to a doctor to help fix them up, but they wouldn’t be able to use that hand anymore. It would be hard for them to do things like eat, write, or play, because they would only have one hand. People in the village might look at them differently, too, because they would remember what they did. So, it was a really tough punishment that changed their whole life.

title: Why does the face get so many more pimples when the hands/feet/arms are in much more contact with dirt etc.?
text: Okay, imagine your skin is like a superhero suit that protects you. Your face is super special because it's often more sensitive and has lots of tiny holes called pores that can get clogged. When dirt, oil, and bacteria from your hands or other places get on your face, they can sneak into those tiny holes and cause pimples, like little villains trying to mess things up. Your hands, feet, and arms can get dirty too, but they usually have thicker skin and less oil, so they don't get as many pimples. Plus, we touch our faces a lot with our hands, which can bring the dirt and germs right to the place where it's easier for them to cause trouble. So, it's important to keep your face clean, just like you would clean your superhero suit to keep it shiny and strong!

title: Why do roads have unnecessary bends?
text: Sometimes roads have bends because they are trying to go around things like trees, rivers, or mountains. If the road were straight, it might have to cut through those things or be really hard to drive on. Bends can also make driving safer because they slow down cars a little, which helps to prevent accidents. Plus, a winding road can be more fun to drive on, almost like a roller coaster! So, even if it seems like a bend is unnecessary, it usually helps make the road better.

title: What happens to our bodies when we don't get enough sleep over a long period of time?
text: When we don’t get enough sleep for a long time, our bodies start to feel really tired and cranky, like how you feel when you miss your nap. Our brains can get fuzzy, making it hard to think clearly or remember things, kind of like trying to see through a foggy window. We might also feel more moody or sad, and our bodies can get sick more easily because sleep helps us fight off germs. Imagine trying to run a race without eating enough food; you’d feel weak and slow! So, just like we need food to be strong, we need sleep to help our bodies and minds work well and feel good.

title: How come full siblings share only 50% genetic with each other and not 100% since they both have the same parents?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons that you share with your brother or sister. Your parents gave you both the same big box, but when you each pick crayons to use, you might not choose the same ones every time. So, even though you both got crayons from the same box, you might have different colors in your drawings. That’s kind of like how siblings get their genes. You get half of your genes from your mom and half from your dad, but when you and your brother or sister get your genes, you might not get the exact same half. Sometimes you both get different pieces from the same parents, which is why you share about 50% of your genes!

title: Why do we remember some dreams, sometimes for years, but tend to forget others right away?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a big box of toys. When you dream, it's like you’re playing with those toys, making up stories and adventures. Some dreams are super fun or really silly, so when you wake up, it's like you found your favorite toy and want to keep it. That's why you remember those dreams for a long time! But other dreams might be boring or just a little weird, like a toy that you don't really like. When you wake up, you might not care about those dreams, so they slip out of your mind quickly, just like putting away a toy you don’t want to play with anymore. So, it’s all about how much fun or interesting the dream is to you!

title: In a box of tissue paper, how does the next piece of tissue come out when you pull out the one above it?
text: Okay, imagine a box of tissue paper is like a stack of soft, thin blankets that are all stuck together at the top. When you pull one tissue out, it has a little special part that helps it grab the next tissue underneath. So, as you pull the top one, it gently pulls the next one up a bit, so it’s ready for you to grab too. It’s like a little game of tug-of-war where the tissues help each other out!

title: Why are floppy discs called "Floppy" if they're not floppy?
text: Floppy disks are called "floppy" because a long time ago, when they were first made, they were actually soft and bendy, like a piece of cloth or a floppy toy. They were made of a thin, flexible plastic that could bend easily. But then, as technology got better, they started making disks that were hard and not floppy at all, like a little hard box. So now, even though the new ones are hard, the name "floppy" stuck because that’s what they were called when they were first made!

title: What happens with plane after emergency landing on water?
text: When a plane has to land on water, it's called a water landing, and it's a big deal! After the plane lands, the pilots and crew will quickly help everyone get out safely. The plane might float for a little while, but it can start to sink if it gets too full of water. The people inside will use life jackets and special rafts to get away from the plane and onto the water. Then, they wait for boats or rescue teams to come and help them. The plane might be taken out of the water later, but the most important thing is that everyone gets out safely first!

title: What are the "natural flavors" listed in some of these zero calorie drinks?
text: Okay, so you know how when you eat fruit, it has a yummy taste? Well, "natural flavors" are like secret recipes made from plants or things in nature that help make drinks and food taste really good without adding sugar or calories. They take things like fruits, spices, or even flowers, and use special methods to take out the tasty bits. Then, they mix those tasty bits into drinks like your zero-calorie soda to make it delicious. So, when you see "natural flavors" on the label, it means they used natural stuff to make your drink taste great without making you gain weight!

title: How do data collectors account for people who put random answers in surveys?
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of crayons and you want to know what colors your friends like best. You ask them to pick their favorite color, but some friends just scribble random colors instead of choosing one. To make sure you get good answers, you can do a few things. First, you can ask some tricky questions that only someone who really thought about their favorite color would know. Second, you can look for patterns, like if someone says they love the color "invisible" – that doesn’t make sense, so you might ignore that answer. Finally, you can ask the same question in different ways to see if people answer the same each time. This way, you can figure out who really thought about their answers and who just wanted to be silly!

title: Why do we salivate and gulp when we are nervous or put on the spot?
text: When we feel nervous or scared, our body gets ready to either run away or fight because it thinks there's danger. This is called the "fight or flight" response. One of the things that happens is that our body makes more saliva, which is the liquid in our mouths that helps us chew food. We might gulp more because our throat feels dry or we want to swallow our nerves, kind of like when you feel a tickle in your tummy and want to get rid of it. So, salivating and gulping is just our body trying to help us deal with feeling nervous!

title: Why does slow motion video of car headlights look like they are blinking rapidly?
text: Okay, imagine you're waving a flashlight really fast in front of your eyes. If you wave it slowly, you can see the light shining in a nice, smooth way. But if you wave it super fast, it looks like the light is blinking on and off really quickly, even though it’s still shining all the time. Now, when a camera records in slow motion, it takes lots and lots of pictures every second. If the car's headlights are turning on and off quickly, the camera can catch those moments really well. So when you watch the video later, it looks like the lights are blinking fast instead of shining steadily. It's just because the camera is showing you all those little moments one after another, making it look like a light show!

title: What causes the feeling of weak muscles when you have a cold or a flu?
text: When you have a cold or the flu, your body is working really hard to fight off the germs that make you sick. It's like when you play a tough game and get really tired afterward. Your body uses a lot of energy to help you feel better, and that can make your muscles feel weak and tired too. Also, sometimes when you're sick, you don't eat or drink as much, which means your body doesn't have enough fuel to keep your muscles strong. So, it's normal to feel like your muscles are weak when you're not feeling well!

title: Why do companies use such low amounts of natural juice in soda, is there a reason for this? And are all the other components really necessary in such amount?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big glass of lemonade, but instead of using a lot of real lemons, you only squeeze in a tiny bit and then fill the rest with water and sugar. That’s kind of what companies do with soda! They want to make it taste sweet and fizzy, so they use a little bit of juice for flavor and a lot of other things like sugar, water, and bubbles to make it yummy and fun to drink. The juice is really expensive, and if they put too much in, it would cost more to make the soda and change how it tastes. The other stuff, like sugar and bubbles, helps make it refreshing and nice to drink, which is why they use those in bigger amounts. So, they mix it all together to make a drink that lots of people enjoy without spending too much money!

title: Why does the body crave bad/fatty foods after a night of drinking alcohol?
text: When you drink alcohol, it can make your tummy feel funny and sometimes it makes you feel really hungry later on. This happens because alcohol can mess with your body and brain, making you want foods that are tasty but not always the healthiest, like greasy burgers or pizza. Your body is looking for quick energy to feel better, and fatty foods give you that energy really fast. Plus, after a night of drinking, your body might be a bit tired and just wants something yummy and comforting to help you feel good again!

title: How can Publishers Clearing House afford to give away $5,000 per week for "forever"?
text: Okay, so imagine Publishers Clearing House (PCH) is like a big treasure chest filled with money! They make a lot of this money by selling things like magazines and other fun stuff. When people enter their contests, they get a chance to win money, but not everyone wins. The money they give away comes from the money they make selling things and from other people who want to advertise their products. So, even though it sounds like a lot to give away $5,000 every week forever, they have a plan and make sure there's enough money in their treasure chest to keep giving prizes for a long time! It's kind of like if you had a piggy bank that you kept filling up with money, and then you took a little out each week to share with your friends!

title: Why is it that, during menstruation, the womb lining is broken down, only to be built up again almost immediately?
text: Okay, imagine your womb is like a cozy little house where a baby could grow. Each month, your body gets ready for a baby by making a soft, warm blanket inside this house, called the womb lining. If a baby doesn’t come to stay, the blanket isn’t needed anymore, so your body cleans it out, and that’s what happens during menstruation—it's like taking away the old blanket. After that, your body starts to make a new blanket again right away, so it’s ready and cozy in case a baby comes next time. It’s like getting your room ready over and over again each month!

title: How does the Queen decide who to knight? There's 1000s of people on this year's honor list how are they aware of them all to know if they deserve an award? Also how do they decide who deserves a CBE vs an OBE vs an MBE etc?
text: Okay, so imagine the Queen is like a really important teacher at a big school, and she gets lots of notes from her friends who tell her about all the kids who are doing really great things. These kids are not just in her school, but in all the schools in the land! People write in to say, "Hey, this person helped a lot of people!" or "This person did something super brave!" Then, a group of helpers, like the teacher’s assistants, read all these notes and pick out the best ones to show to the Queen. When she looks at the names, she thinks about how special each kid's actions are. Now, about the different awards like CBE, OBE, and MBE: it’s like giving out different kinds of shiny stickers. If someone did something really, really amazing, they might get a CBE sticker. If they did something great, they could get an OBE sticker. And if they did something good, they might get an MBE sticker. So, the more special the thing they did, the shinier the sticker!

title: What exactly is a Diplomat and why do we have them?
text: A diplomat is like a special helper that talks to other countries to keep everyone friendly and solve problems. Imagine if you and your friends had a disagreement about sharing toys; a diplomat is like a wise grown-up who helps you talk it out instead of fighting. They go to different countries, meet important people, and make deals to help everyone get along. We have them because it’s important for countries to communicate and work together peacefully, just like friends do!

title: Why was amputation so common during the Civil War?
text: Amputation was common during the Civil War because doctors had to make quick decisions to save soldiers' lives when they got hurt. Many soldiers got really bad injuries, like broken bones or infections, and sometimes their arms or legs were damaged too much to fix. Instead of just trying to bandage the hurt part, which could take a long time and might not work, doctors would cut off the injured arm or leg to help the soldier get better faster and stop the sickness from spreading. They didn’t have the same medicines and tools we have today, so amputation was often the best way to save a life back then.

title: What would happen to astronauts in orbit if earth instantly disappeared?
text: If the Earth suddenly disappeared, the astronauts in orbit would still be floating around in their spaceship, just like they were before. That's because they are already moving really fast and are in a special place called "orbit," which means they are going around the Earth. Without Earth, they would keep going in a straight line, away from where Earth used to be. They wouldn't feel any different at first, but eventually, they would need to find a new place to live or come back to Earth, which is now gone. They would also have to be careful because they wouldn't have the air to breathe and would need to find a way to stay safe in space.

title: Why do potato chips' such as: Ketchup, All Dressed, and Dill Pickle sales tests perform so poorly in the US, but are among the top flavours in other countries?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons, and each crayon is a different flavor of potato chips. In some countries, like Canada, people really love the colors like Ketchup, All Dressed, and Dill Pickle because they are used to those flavors and think they taste yummy. But in the US, people might like different colors or flavors more, like BBQ or Sour Cream and Onion. It’s a bit like how some kids like chocolate ice cream while others prefer vanilla. So, when chip makers try to sell those special flavors in the US, not as many people want to buy them because they’re not used to them or don’t think they’ll taste good. It’s all about what people are used to and what they like!

title: Why is the side order of fruit at American restaurants an overwhelming amount of cantaloupe and honeydew?
text: Okay, so imagine you go to a restaurant and you want something yummy to go with your meal, like fruit! Cantaloupe and honeydew are two types of melons that are really popular because they are sweet, juicy, and easy to cut into bite-sized pieces. They also don't get brown like apples or bananas do, so they look nice on your plate. Plus, they are usually cheap for restaurants to buy in big amounts. So when they want to give you a tasty side of fruit, they often choose cantaloupe and honeydew because they are colorful, yummy, and easy for everyone to enjoy!

title: Why does boiling water soften pasta and vegetables, but harden eggs?
text: Okay, imagine pasta and vegetables are like little sponges that soak up water. When you put them in boiling water, they get really hot and soft, kind of like when you leave a sponge in water for a long time. The heat helps break down their hard parts, so they become nice and chewy or crunchy. Now, eggs are different! They have a special part called protein, which is like tiny strings that are all loose and wiggly when the egg is raw. But when you heat them up, those strings get tight and all stuck together, making the egg hard. So, boiling water makes pasta and veggies soft because they soak up water, but it makes eggs hard because the heat changes their structure!

title: Why does cabin depressurization cause a plane to crash?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with a balloon. When you blow air into it, the balloon gets big and puffy, right? Now, if there’s a hole in the balloon, the air inside starts to escape, and the balloon can get all floppy and sad. A plane is like that balloon but way stronger! When a plane is flying high in the sky, the air outside is very thin, and the air inside the plane helps keep everyone safe and comfy. If a cabin depressurization happens, it means that the air inside the plane is escaping too quickly, like the hole in the balloon. This can make it hard for people to breathe and can make the plane feel funny. The pilots and crew are trained to fix this and help everyone, so a depressurization doesn’t automatically mean the plane will crash, but it can be very serious and scary if it happens!

title: Why does holding down the power button on devices work even when the system is frozen?
text: Okay, imagine your device is like a toy robot that sometimes gets stuck or stops moving. When you hold down the power button, it's like giving that robot a little shake to wake it up! The robot doesn’t know what to do anymore, so when you shake it, it just stops everything it was doing and resets itself. So, even if it seems frozen, pressing and holding the power button tells it, "Hey, time to stop and start over!" This helps it work again, just like how you might need to restart a game if it freezes.

title: What is that feeling we get in our stomach when we're hungry? Why does it happen?
text: When you're hungry, you might feel a funny, rumbling feeling in your tummy, kind of like a little monster is making noise! This happens because your body is telling you it needs food. When your tummy is empty, it sends signals to your brain, saying, "Hey, I need some yummy food to eat!" This makes you feel that weird feeling, and sometimes you might even hear your stomach growl. It’s like your body’s way of reminding you to eat so you can have energy to play and grow!

title: A deer can eat poisonous plants like rhoderdendrons because they don't have a gall bladder. When a doctor removes a humans gall bladder, are they too able to eat poison without feeling ill?
text: No, people can't eat poison just because they don't have a gall bladder. The gall bladder is a little pouch that helps store a juice called bile, which helps us digest food, especially fatty foods. When doctors take out a person's gall bladder, their body can still digest food, but it might not work as well with fatty stuff. However, poison is different! Even without a gall bladder, people still have other parts in their body that can get hurt by poison. So, eating something poisonous is still very dangerous for humans, gall bladder or not!

title: how can the identity of icefrog, someone who makes dota 2, one of the biggest games in the world, be unknown?
text: IceFrog is like a superhero who makes a really fun game called Dota 2, but nobody knows who he is because he likes to keep his identity a secret, just like how some superheroes wear masks. He wants people to focus on the game and not on him, so he can make it better without all the attention. It's a little like if your favorite cartoon character was a mystery, and you enjoyed the stories they told instead of worrying about who created them. So, even though lots of people play Dota 2 and love it, IceFrog chooses to stay hidden, and that makes him special!

title: When they say "we didn't have the technology then," what does that specifically refer to? Why were USB sticks only able to hold 500 MB a few years ago but are now able to hold hundreds of GB? What specifically changes in that time frame?
text: When people say "we didn't have the technology then," they mean that scientists and inventors hadn't figured out how to make things better and smaller yet. Think of it like building with blocks: a long time ago, people only had big, clunky blocks to build with, so they could only make small towers. But then, over time, they invented new, smaller blocks that fit more pieces together, allowing them to build much bigger towers! For USB sticks, the way they store information got better. A few years ago, the materials and designs used inside the USB sticks were not as advanced, so they could only hold a little bit of information, like 500 MB, which is like a few books. Now, scientists have found new ways to pack information into those tiny sticks much better, like squeezing more books into the same backpack, so now they can hold hundreds of gigabytes, which is like having a whole library! So, when technology improves, it means we can do things we couldn't do before, like making USB sticks that hold more and more information.

title: What stops us from getting cell phone interference?
text: Okay, so imagine if everyone was trying to talk to each other at the same time using walkie-talkies. It would get all mixed up and loud, right? To stop that from happening with cell phones, we have something called "frequencies" which are like different channels for each walkie-talkie. Each cell phone uses a special channel to talk and listen, so they don’t bump into each other and cause interference. Also, there are big towers called cell towers that help send and receive signals from your phone, making sure everything stays clear, just like a teacher helping kids talk without getting mixed up. Plus, phones have little smart brains inside them that help keep everything organized and running smoothly!

title: When you have a good stare going on, what is actually happening and why does it feel so good to keep it going?
text: When you have a good stare going on, it means you are looking at something really interesting or beautiful, like a cute puppy or a pretty picture. What's happening is your brain is getting super happy because it likes what it sees. It's like when you eat yummy candy, your brain releases happy chemicals that make you feel good. Staring at something you love can make you feel calm and focused, kind of like when you listen to your favorite song and want to hear it again and again. So, the more you stare, the happier your brain feels, and that's why it feels so good to keep looking!

title: How does military strategy work? What are some of the broadest theoretical frameworks for military strategy and history?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are playing a big game of tag in a big park. Military strategy is kind of like coming up with a smart plan for how to win that game. You need to think about where to hide, how to move around without getting caught, and how to tag your friends without them tagging you back. Some big ideas in military strategy are like having a strong team, using the right tools, and knowing when to be sneaky or when to be brave. One idea is called "defense," where you protect your team and wait for the right moment to make a move. Another idea is "offense," where you try to tag as many people as you can quickly. There are also ideas about working together with other teams or using surprise to catch others off guard. Just like in tag, the best plans can help you win, but you need to think ahead and be smart about what you do!

title: What determines your blood type and what's the difference between positive and negative?
text: Okay, so your blood type is like a special label that tells us what kind of blood you have, and it’s decided by tiny things in your blood called markers. Imagine these markers are like little stickers on your blood cells. There are different kinds of stickers, and the most common ones are A, B, AB, and O. Now, when we say someone is "positive" or "negative," we’re talking about another little marker called the Rh factor. If you have this Rh marker sticker, you’re “positive,” like A positive or O positive. If you don’t have it, you’re “negative,” like A negative or O negative. It’s important to know your blood type, especially if you ever need a blood transfusion, because you want to make sure your blood matches the other person's blood so your body stays happy and healthy!

title: What would happen to the body if the air you're breathing is thin, like that of people who climb Mount Everest? If you were exposed to this for long periods of time what would happen to your body overtime?
text: Okay, imagine you're trying to blow up a balloon, but there isn’t much air around you. That’s sort of what it’s like when you breathe thin air, like on top of Mount Everest. Your body needs air with a good amount of oxygen to feel strong and happy. If you breathe thin air for a long time, your body gets tired and doesn’t work as well. It’s like trying to run really fast but only having a little bit of energy. At first, you might feel dizzy or have a headache, like when you spin around too fast. If you stay up there too long, your body tries to fix things by making more red blood cells, which are like little delivery trucks that carry oxygen. But if you don’t come back down to where there’s more air, those trucks can get too busy and start causing problems, making your head hurt more or even making it hard to breathe. So, being in thin air for a long time is like trying to do a really hard puzzle without enough pieces; it makes everything tougher and can make you feel sick.

title: Does poetry in other languages rhyme the same way poems in English rhyme?
text: Poetry in other languages can rhyme, but it doesn’t always rhyme the same way as poems in English. Different languages have their own sounds and ways of putting words together, so the rhymes can be different. For example, in English, we might have "cat" and "hat" rhyme because they end with the same sound. In Spanish, you might find "casa" and "masa" rhyme, which sounds different from English. So, while all languages can have rhymes, the way they sound and the patterns they use can be unique to each language!

title: Why is the feeling of impending doom a real symptom and how does someone know they're dying?
text: Okay, imagine you’re playing outside and suddenly you feel really scared, like something bad is going to happen, even if you don’t see anything wrong. That’s kind of like what people feel when they have a feeling of impending doom. It’s a strong feeling that tells your brain, “Uh-oh, something is not right!” Sometimes, when someone is very sick or hurt, their body can send these signals to warn them that something serious might be happening, like something with their heart or lungs. When people feel this way, they might notice other things too, like feeling very tired, having trouble breathing, or feeling a lot of pain. It's like when you know you need to tell an adult that something is wrong because your tummy hurts or you fell down. If someone feels this way, it’s important for them to talk to a doctor who can help figure out what’s going on.

title: Why is it easier to take hot showers rather than cold ones?
text: Taking a hot shower feels easier and nicer because the warm water makes your body feel cozy and relaxed, like being wrapped in a warm blanket. When you step under hot water, it helps to loosen your muscles and can even make you feel sleepy, which is why many people like it. Cold showers, on the other hand, can feel shocking and make your body want to shiver and get warm again, which is not as comfortable. So, hot showers are like a warm hug, while cold showers are like a surprise splash of cold water that makes you feel wide awake!

title: As I lie here at 3am I wonder- why do people have trouble falling asleep at a reasonable time even when they wake up early and are tired during the day?
text: Okay, so imagine your brain is like a big, busy city! During the day, lots of cars (or thoughts) are zooming around, and it's really energetic. But when it's nighttime, your city needs to quiet down so the people (you) can go to sleep.
