title: Why do we say that looks aren't important when we actually get attracted more by looks than personality?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons. Some crayons are really bright and colorful, and they catch your eye right away, just like how someone might look nice or pretty. But when you start coloring, you realize that the best pictures come from the crayons that are a little less shiny but work really well and make beautiful colors when you use them. So, while it's fun to see the pretty crayons first, what really matters is how well they help you create your picture. That's why people say looks aren't everything; we want someone who is nice and fun to be around, just like using crayons that really help you make the best art!

title: Why does hot water feel significantly hotter on my face than on other parts of my body?
text: Hot water feels hotter on your face because the skin on your face is more sensitive than the skin on other parts of your body. Think of your face like a little superhero that can feel things really well! It has lots of tiny sensors that tell your brain when something is hot or cold. When hot water touches your face, those sensors send a strong message to your brain that says, "Ouch, that's hot!" But on places like your arms or legs, the skin isn't as sensitive, so the hot water doesn’t feel as bad. It's like how you might feel tickles more on your tummy than on your back!

title: Can you sneeze in your sleep?
text: No, you can't really sneeze in your sleep. When you're asleep, your body is in a special resting mode, and it doesn’t always react to things like it does when you're awake. Sneezing happens because something bothers your nose, like dust or a tickle, and your brain tells your body to sneeze to get rid of it. But when you're asleep, your brain isn't paying attention to those things as much, so you usually don’t sneeze. If you wake up and feel like you need to sneeze, that's because your body is waking up again and can notice things again!

title: Why does prolonged screen time make me feel so drained?
text: When you look at screens for a long time, your brain has to work really hard to understand what's happening, like reading or watching videos. It’s like trying to solve a puzzle, and that can make your brain feel tired, just like your legs get tired after running. Also, screens can be really bright, and the blue light they give off can make it hard for your eyes to relax, which can also make you feel tired. Plus, when you stare at screens, you might forget to blink or move around, and that can make your body feel sleepy and drained too. So, it’s important to take breaks, just like taking a rest after playing for a long time!

title: If black coffee and diet pop are mostly water, why do they not hydrate the body?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a sponge, and it needs water to stay happy and healthy. Black coffee and diet pop have a lot of water, but they also have other things in them. Black coffee has caffeine, which can make you feel jumpy and might even make you pee more, so you lose water instead of keeping it. Diet pop has stuff called artificial sweeteners, which can also confuse your body. So even though these drinks have water, they can make you lose more water than they give you, and that's why they're not the best for hydrating your body! It's like trying to fill a sponge with a leaky cup; it just doesn’t work very well! The best way to hydrate is still plain water!

title: How come soldiers today don't wear full armour that covers their entire body? Knights were able to move easily and with todays technology making a soldier bulletproof should be easy.
text: Great question! So, a long time ago, knights wore heavy armor that covered them all over to protect them from swords and arrows. It worked well for fighting back then, but today’s battles are very different because soldiers face bullets and bombs. Full armor like knights wore would be super heavy and hard to move in, making it hard for soldiers to run, jump, or take cover quickly when they need to. Today, we use lighter materials that can stop bullets, like special vests called body armor, which protect important parts of the body but still let soldiers move around easily. Plus, soldiers also have to carry a lot of other gear, like food and water, so being too heavy would make it really tough for them to do their jobs! So, it’s all about finding a balance between protection and being able to move fast.

title: Why are Credit Ratings Agencies Private For-Profit Institutions?
text: Credit rating agencies are like teachers that give grades to companies or countries about how good they are at paying back money they borrow. These agencies are private for-profit businesses, which means they try to make money while doing their job. They are private because it allows them to work independently and not be controlled by the government. Being for-profit means they can charge companies money to check their grades and give them ratings. This helps the agencies stay in business and pay their workers. Just like how a lemonade stand needs to make money to keep selling lemonade, credit rating agencies need to make money to keep rating companies and helping people decide who is safe to lend money to.

title: Why do Kettle chips get different bags?
text: Kettle chips get different bags because they want to show off all the yummy flavors they make! Just like how your favorite toys come in different colors and shapes, Kettle chips come in different bags to help you know what tasty flavor is inside, like sea salt, barbecue, or sour cream and onion. So, the different bags are like fun outfits for the chips!

title: Why does sunlight bleach/lighten things?
text: Sunlight can bleach or lighten things because it has special rays called ultraviolet (UV) rays that are super strong. Imagine these rays like tiny superheroes that can break apart colors in things like clothes, paper, or even your favorite toys when they are left outside too long. When the sunlight shines on them, these superhero rays make the colors fade away, kind of like how a crayon gets smaller when you use it a lot. That's why if you leave a red shirt outside in the sun, it might turn pink over time!

title: Why does a goldfish die when you transfer him form muddy water to clean water ?
text: When you move a goldfish from muddy water to clean water, it can get really confused and stressed out. The muddy water has lots of tiny things in it that the fish is used to, like special germs and stuff that help it stay healthy. Clean water doesn't have those things, so when the fish is suddenly put in, it can feel like a big change, almost like jumping into a pool that feels too cold. Plus, if the clean water is very different in temperature or how much stuff is dissolved in it (like salt or chemicals), it can hurt the fish's body. Goldfish need time to get used to new water, just like we need a little time to get used to new places. If they can't adjust, they can get really sick or even die.

title: Why can't helium balloons float upside down?
text: Helium balloons can't float upside down because helium is lighter than the air around us. When you let go of a helium balloon, it goes up because the air is heavier than the balloon filled with helium. But if you turn it upside down, the balloon still wants to go up, and the air pushes down on it. So, if the balloon is upside down, the air can hold it down instead of letting it float. It's kind of like if you tried to hold a beach ball underwater; it wants to pop back up to the surface!

title: What happens to a photon when it hits your retina?
text: When a tiny light particle called a photon hits your retina, which is like the back wall of your eye, it gets absorbed by special cells in there. These cells are like tiny helpers that can feel the light. When the photon touches them, it makes them send a message to your brain saying, "Hey, I see light!" Your brain then takes that message and helps you see things around you, like colors and shapes. So, when a photon hits your retina, it starts the whole process of seeing the world!

title: Is there an advantage to using the Imperial System of measurement instead of the Metric System?
text: Okay, imagine you have two different kinds of measuring cups for baking cookies. The Imperial System is like a cup that uses things like inches and pounds, which some people in the U.S. are really used to and know how to use well. So if you’re making a cake and your mom always uses that cup, it might be easier for her to stick with it. The Metric System is like a fancy cup that uses centimeters and grams, and it’s used by a lot of other countries around the world because it’s super simple to understand. You can easily add or take away numbers because everything goes up by tens. So, the advantage of the Imperial System is that it’s familiar for some people, like how they know how many inches are in a foot, but the Metric System is usually easier for math and sharing with friends around the world.

title: How long should food take to journey from the mouth to the bathroom?
text: When you eat food, it goes on a little trip in your body! First, it goes down your throat and into your tummy, where it gets mixed up and squished. Then, it travels through a long tube called the intestines, where your body takes all the good stuff it needs, like energy. This whole trip usually takes about 24 to 72 hours, which is like one to three days. So, after you eat, it can take a little while before you see that food again when you go to the bathroom!

title: I imagine that if I were in a position of power I'd be so overwhelmed with my opportunity to serve the people that it'd be all I could think about. How is it that seemingly every politician becomes self serving by the time they reach power?
text: Sometimes when people get a lot of power, like politicians, it's like they get a big shiny toy that they really want to keep for themselves. It can be hard to remember the important things when there are so many distractions, like money or fame, and sometimes they start to care more about those things than about helping everyone else. title: How do we define the age of a meteoroid? (so how old is this piece of rock from space, when it's older than the earth itself?)
text: Okay, imagine you have a really old rock that fell from the sky, and we want to know how old it is. To figure this out, scientists use something like a special clock called "radiometric dating." This is like checking the age of a tree by counting its rings, but instead, they look at tiny bits inside the rock called "elements." Some of these elements change over time at a steady rate, like a timer. By measuring how much of these elements are left in the rock and how much has changed, they can tell us how long it has been since the rock was made. Some meteoroids are super old, even older than the Earth, because they come from places like asteroids that formed a long, long time ago when the solar system was just starting. So, by using these special clocks, scientists can find out just how ancient those space rocks really are!

title: Why do you sometimes wake up with a headache if you've slept for too long (i.e. more than 9 hours)?
text: Sometimes when you sleep for a really long time, like more than 9 hours, your brain might get a bit confused or upset. It's like when you eat too much candy and your tummy hurts. So, waking up with a headache after sleeping too long is just your body telling you, "Hey, I need a little balance!"

title: why can't jedis use the force to turn off their opponents lightsaber?

title: How is it possible that steel has a scent?

So, when you smell steel, it's really just your nose noticing those tiny bits that are around it!

title: Can't you simply guess a PaySafeCard pin since it only contains numbers?
text: Guessing a PaySafeCard pin is really, really hard, kind of like trying to guess a secret code! A PaySafeCard pin has 16 numbers, and each number can be anything from 0 to 9. title: Why is Uber losing so much money and how can they still afford to be up and running?
text: Okay, imagine you have a lemonade stand. You want to sell lemonade, but you also have to buy lemons, sugar, cups, and a table. title: What happens if an animal who is supposed to hibernate is unable to?
text: If an animal that's supposed to hibernate can't, it's like trying to sleep when there's too much noise. title: How does stress cause acne?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a superhero team. When you get stressed, it's like the alarm bells are ringing, and your superhero team gets really busy trying to help you feel better. One of the things they do is make a special juice called hormones. These hormones can tell your skin to make more oil, which is like the slippery stuff that can get on your face. If your skin makes too much oil, it can mix with dirt and tiny bits of dead skin, and that can get stuck in your pores, which are like tiny holes in your skin. When that happens, it can cause little bumps called acne. So, stress makes your superheroes work extra hard, and sometimes that makes your skin a bit messy!

title: If a nuclear missile is launched, why can't someone just shoot it down while it is still high in the air?

title: Is it really important to human in critical condition to stay conscious, and why?
text: Yes, it's really important for a person in critical condition to stay conscious because it helps doctors know how they're feeling and what they need. Staying conscious also means the person can breathe better and their heart can work properly. title: Why do humans laugh in bursts like "Ha ha ha" instead of one long "haaaaaaaaaaa"?
text: Humans laugh in bursts like "Ha ha ha" because it's like a fun little game our bodies play! title: Why is it that major internet service providers are starting to add bandwidth limits? Shouldn't service get better and less restrictive as infrastructure improves?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons and you want to share them with all your friends. If you let everyone use as many crayons as they want, some friends might take a lot and use them up really quickly, leaving not many for others. So, to make sure everyone gets to use the crayons, you might say, "You can only use 5 crayons at a time." This is kind of like what internet service providers (ISPs) are doing with bandwidth limits. They want to make sure that everyone can use the internet without it getting too slow. Even though the internet can be faster and better now, if too many people use too much at the same time, it can still get crowded and slow. So, they add limits to keep things fair and make sure everyone has a chance to enjoy the internet!

title: How can a touchscreen project black in a power saving way (details on the screen inside)?
text: Okay, imagine your touchscreen is like a big, flat magic window that shows you pictures and words. When you want to see something, the window lights up with colors and designs. Now, when the window shows black, it’s like turning off certain lights inside the magic window, so it doesn’t use as much energy. Inside the screen, there are tiny little lights called pixels that can change colors. When they need to show black, they don’t turn on at all, which means they’re saving energy, just like when you turn off a light in a room when you don’t need it. This way, the touchscreen can still work well and look nice, but it uses less power, helping your tablet or phone last longer without needing a recharge!

title: Why are we cool with moldy cheese but freak out over moldy bread?
text: Okay, so think of cheese and bread like two different kinds of food. This good mold is safe to eat and can be part of the cheese. But bread, on the other hand, usually gets a bad kind of mold when it gets old, and that mold can make you sick. So, it’s all about what kind of mold is on the food!

title: why do we feel the urge to chew/pick at/mess with sores in our mouth, even though we know doing so will make it worse?

title: Why is it that some people don't know how to swim or even float in water?

title: Why do top nutrition advisory panels continue to change their guidelines (sometimes dramatically) on what constitutes a healthy diet?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons, and every time you draw a picture, you learn something new about which colors look best together. title: What are the main differences between the Canadian government and American government ?
text: Okay, so imagine the Canadian government and the American government are like two different teams that play a game, but they have some different rules and ways to do things. In Canada, the leader is called the Prime Minister, and the country is a "parliamentary system," which means the people who make the laws are part of a big group called Parliament. In the USA, the leader is called the President, and they have a "presidential system," where the President is separate from the group that makes the laws, called Congress. Also, Canada is a little more like a family with a big queen or king watching over it from far away, while the USA is more like a big team that decided to do its own thing and not have a king or queen. Lastly, Canada has more provinces, like different parts of a big city, while the USA has states, which are also like different parts but have their own special rules too. So, even though both countries want to keep their people happy and safe, they play the government game in slightly different ways!

title: Please explain the Star Trek Stardate calendar system. Is it nonsense or based on something scientifical?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big space adventure with lots of different planets and stars, just like in Star Trek! Now, instead of using our regular calendar with days and months like we do on Earth, they use something called "stardates," which is a special way to keep track of time in space. Stardates are a little bit like a secret code that helps everyone in space know when things are happening. They don’t follow a regular pattern like our calendar; instead, they change based on how far into their adventures they are. The creators of Star Trek didn’t want to stick to our Earth time, so they made up stardates to sound cool and fit the fun space stories. Some parts of it are based on real science, like how we measure time with numbers, but mostly it’s just a creative way to make the show feel more exciting and different! So, it’s not nonsense, but it’s not really a real calendar either—it's just part of the fun of space stories!

title: What is the uncomfortable feeling after laying on one side of your body for too long, making you want to switch sides?

title: Why do some people have an overwhelming urge to playfully bite newborn babies? "I just want to eat them up!" etc.
text: Sometimes, when people see really cute babies, they feel a strong, happy feeling that makes them want to squeeze or nibble on them, kind of like how you might feel when you see a cute puppy or kitten. title: how is it that sometimes when we wake up from a dream we don't remember what happened but we remember that it was a scary, good, or weird dream?
text: When you dream, your brain is like a movie theater showing a special film. title: Why do some websites say it takes 72 hours to remove you from their mailing list? Why isn't it instantaneous?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and every time a friend wants to play with one, you have to go find it in that box. title: Why is it that some phone apps which use the camera have horrible focus and take crappy pictures compared to the stock camera app?

title: Is it possible for a 5,8ft male to eat only 1200 calories per day, to lose weight, if he has no real muscles to begin with?
text: Okay, so imagine your body is like a car that needs fuel to run. The fuel is the food you eat, and calories are like the gas for your car. If a tall guy, like someone who is 5 feet 8 inches, only eats 1200 calories a day, that’s like giving a big car just a little bit of gas.
