title: how come some people perspire much more than others?
text: Some people sweat more than others because our bodies are all a little different, just like how some people are taller or have different hair colors. Sweating helps keep us cool when we get hot, like when we run or play outside. Some folks have more sweat glands, which are tiny parts in our skin that make sweat, so they sweat more. Also, things like how much exercise we do, what we eat, and even how we feel can change how much we sweat. So, it's just our bodies being unique!

title: Why have I never heard of an animal fainting? Is it rarer for them to faint than humans or something similar?
text: Okay, so when humans faint, it’s like our body is saying, “I need a little break!” This can happen because we get too hot, scared, or dizzy. Animals can faint too, but it happens less often than with people. This is because animals have different bodies and ways of dealing with things. Some animals, like dogs or cats, might get scared or too hot, but instead of fainting, they might just lay down or take a nap. Also, animals are really good at listening to their bodies, so they usually don’t push themselves too hard. So, it's not that animals can’t faint, it’s just that it’s not something we see very often!

title: With the current way the earth orbits the sun, are the hottest seasons for the equator spring and fall?
text: Nope, the hottest seasons for the equator aren't spring and fall. The equator is like a big belt around the middle of the Earth, and it gets a lot of sunshine all year long. So, it doesn’t really have seasons like spring, summer, fall, and winter like places further away from the equator do. Instead, it stays warm and sunny, and sometimes it can get rainy. The temperature doesn't change much throughout the year, so it's pretty much hot all the time!

title: What happens when you go into a coma? Is it just a very long dream?
text: When someone goes into a coma, it's like their brain is taking a really long nap, but they can't wake up. During this time, they don’t know what's happening around them, and they can't see, hear, or feel things like we do when we're awake. It's not like a dream because they aren't thinking or dreaming like we do when we sleep. Their body might still be working, like their heart is beating and they might breathe, but they are not aware of anything. Doctors help take care of them, and sometimes, people wake up from a coma, but it can take a long time, and it's different for everyone.

title: Does true randomness exist?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big bag of colorful marbles, and you want to pick one without looking. If you reach in and grab one, it feels like you’re being random because you don’t know which color you’ll get. But if you keep picking marbles, you might notice that some colors are more common than others, and that can make it seem less random. In the world, true randomness is like that: sometimes things seem random, like flipping a coin or rolling dice, but they can still be influenced by other things, like how hard you throw or how the coin is shaped. Scientists say there are some really tiny things, like particles in space, that might act randomly all the time, but we don’t know for sure. So, it’s like a puzzle we’re still trying to figure out!

title: Why is there a notable distinction in taste between food that is hot and cold?
text: Okay, imagine your tongue is like a tiny superhero that can taste things! When you eat hot food, like soup, it warms up your tongue and makes the flavors come out more, kind of like how a flower opens up in the sunshine. Hot food can taste yummy and strong because the heat helps the flavors mix together better. Now, when you eat cold food, like ice cream, it cools down your tongue, and sometimes the flavors don’t come out as much. Cold can make things taste sweeter or different because it changes how your tongue feels. So, hot food and cold food can taste different because of how they warm or cool your tongue and how that affects the flavors you taste!

title: What's the difference between LFTR reactors and traditional nuclear reactors? And if they're safer, why aren't we using them instead?
text: Okay, imagine a traditional nuclear reactor like a big pot of soup that gets really hot because of special ingredients called uranium. This soup makes steam, which helps turn a wheel to make electricity. But sometimes, if things go wrong, the soup can boil over or even spill, which can be dangerous. Now, a LFTR reactor, which stands for Liquid Fluoride Thorium Reactor, is like a magic soup pot that uses a different ingredient called thorium and instead of being solid, the soup is liquid. This means if something goes wrong, it can just flow away safely and not spill everywhere. Plus, it makes a lot less waste and is better for the environment! But the reason we don't use them yet is because they are still kind of new and people need to figure out how to make them work really well and safely before we can use them everywhere. It’s like learning to ride a bike; you need to practice a lot before you can ride it without falling!

title: What goes on with blacklights that fudge up the visuals when in them, like glow-in-the-dark mini-golf?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a special kind of light called a blacklight. This light is really good at making certain things glow in the dark, like the fun colorful stuff you see in mini-golf! When the blacklight shines, it makes some colors look super bright and shiny because they have special magic in them called “fluorescence.” But, not everything glows the same way. Some colors might look weird or even disappear because they don't react to the blacklight. So, when you’re playing mini-golf, the blacklight makes the colorful decorations pop out, but it can also make some things look strange or hard to see. It’s like having a magic flashlight that makes some toys look extra cool but makes other toys hard to find!

title: What is the difference between the US Senate and House of Representatives?
text: Okay! So, imagine the U.S. government is like a big team trying to make rules for everyone in the country. There are two parts of this team: the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate is like a small group of older kids who each get to make important decisions, and there are 100 of them, two from each state. They usually take a little more time to think things over because they want to make sure their choices are really good. On the other hand, the House of Representatives is like a bigger group with lots of kids, 435 in total, and they represent different parts of the country based on how many people live there. They get to suggest new rules and make decisions faster because there are more of them. So, the Senate and the House work together to make the best rules for everyone, but they do it in different ways!

title: Why is it that teeth come in symmetrical pairs but aren't all the same shape?
text: Okay, so imagine your mouth is like a little tool box, and each tooth is a different tool that helps you chew food. Some teeth are sharp like little scissors, and those are the ones at the front called incisors, and they're great for biting into apples. Then there are the bigger, flatter teeth at the back called molars, and they are like big, strong hammers that help crush up food. Now, even though the teeth come in pairs—like having two scissors or two hammers—they need to be different shapes so they can do their own special jobs. So, when you smile, you have a nice set of tools that work together to help you eat!

title: Now that we're seeing 10 gigabit USB and even faster Thunderbolt on laptops, how come we dont have any laptops with 10 gigabit ethernet?
text: Okay, so imagine your laptop is like a super-fast car that can zoom around really quickly! Now, USB and Thunderbolt are like special highways that let your car go super fast and carry lots of things at once. But when it comes to 10 gigabit ethernet, which is like a different kind of road for sending information, not all laptops have that kind of road yet. This is because making 10 gigabit ethernet is a bit more complicated and costs more money, so not every laptop maker puts it in. Plus, most people don’t need it right now because regular internet is fast enough for what they do, like watching videos or playing games. But as more people want super-fast connections, we might start seeing more laptops with that special road too!

title: How do computers restart?
text: Okay, imagine your computer is like a toy that sometimes gets a little sleepy or confused. When you restart it, it's like giving that toy a little nap so it can wake up fresh and ready to play again! First, the computer tells all its parts, "Hey, time to stop what you're doing!" Then it closes everything, like putting your toys back in their box. After that, it turns itself off for a quick second, like closing your eyes for a nap. Finally, it opens its eyes again and starts up all over, like waking up and getting ready to play! This helps it run better and fix any little problems it might have had.

title: How does the cord of my earphones get all tangled up in several impossible knots?
text: Okay, so imagine your earphone cord is like a little snake that likes to wiggle around. When you put it in your bag or pocket, it moves and twists because it’s all squished up. Sometimes, it gets caught on other things or just decides to wrap around itself, kind of like when you try to tie your shoelaces and they get all mixed up. The more you pull it out and put it back, the more it gets tangled, like a game of hide-and-seek where the snake hides in knots! So, to avoid that, you can try to roll it up neatly and keep it in a little pouch, just like putting your toys away nicely after playing.

title: What is the USPS's relationship to the federal government?
text: The USPS, or United States Postal Service, is like a big mail delivery company that helps people send letters and packages all over the country. It is part of the federal government, which means it is connected to the rules and laws that the government makes. However, it's a little different because it tries to make its own money by charging for stamps and services, instead of just getting money from taxes like other government agencies. So, it works on its own to deliver mail, but it still has to follow the government's rules and help everyone, just like a good neighbor!

title: How does schizophrenia develop and what exactly does it do to the brain?
text: Okay, so imagine your brain is like a big city with lots of busy roads and traffic lights that help everything work smoothly. Schizophrenia is like when some of the traffic lights start to malfunction, and the roads get all mixed up. This can make it hard for people to think clearly, remember things, or understand what’s real and what’s not. Scientists aren’t completely sure why this happens, but they think it might be caused by a mix of things like genes (the stuff that makes you, you), changes in the brain's chemicals that help send messages, and maybe some stressful experiences. So, when someone has schizophrenia, their brain might show unusual patterns or changes in how it works, which can lead to seeing or hearing things that aren’t there, feeling really confused, or acting in ways that seem strange to others. It’s like having a really noisy and messy city in your head!

title: In movie/tv scenes where "animals were not harmed", how do they show the animals being harmed when not using cgi ?
text: Okay, so when you see a movie or a TV show and they say "no animals were harmed," it means they took special care to make sure the animals are safe and happy while filming. They can show animals being harmed or in danger without actually hurting them by using clever tricks. For example, they might film the animal doing something normal, like playing, and then edit the video to make it look like something scary is happening. They can also use fake animals, like dolls or models, to show things happening to them. Sometimes, they use trained actors who pretend to be the animals or even use costumes! So, it looks real on screen, but the real animals are just fine and having fun.

title: why is it in northern states (US) it can snow several feet and daily life doesn't change, but in southern states ~1 inch of snow can shut everything down?
text: Okay, imagine if you lived in a place where it rains a lot, like a big city with lots of umbrellas and raincoats. People there know how to deal with rain, so they keep going to school and work even if it pours. Now, think about a place where it hardly ever rains. If it rains just a little, everyone gets super confused because they don’t have umbrellas or rain boots, and they don’t know how to drive in the rain. In the northern states, they have a lot of snow every winter, so they have special trucks with big plows to clear the roads, and people have warm clothes and know how to walk and drive in snow. But in the southern states, when they get a little snow, they don’t have those trucks or warm clothes ready because they usually don’t need them. So, when it snows even a tiny bit, it can make everything a big mess, and people stay home because they don’t know what to do!

title: How do Internet Routers transmit data from a PC through their device and then to the internet?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy train set. Your PC is like a little train that wants to send messages to your friends who live far away. But it can't just go by itself; it needs a helper! That helper is the internet router, which is like a big train station. When your little train (the PC) has a message to send, it goes to the train station (the router). The router looks at where the message needs to go and sends it on the right track to the internet, which is like a giant network of train tracks connecting all the toy train stations in the world. Once the message gets to the right station, it can go to your friend's PC, and then they can send a message back to you the same way! So, the router helps your PC find the right path to send messages to other computers far away.

title: Why do some people feel slow and negative in the mornings while others are energetic and positive?
text: Some people feel slow and negative in the mornings because their bodies and brains wake up differently. Imagine a car that needs a little time to warm up before it can go fast; that's like some people's brains in the morning. They might not have slept well or they might just like to take their time waking up. On the other hand, some people feel energetic and positive because they wake up ready to go, like a race car that’s ready to zoom! They might have had a good night's sleep or they might just be excited about the day ahead. Everyone is different, just like how some kids like chocolate ice cream and others like vanilla!

title: Why does the login page for Google or Microsoft accounts separate the username and password fields into different screens?
text: The login page for Google or Microsoft accounts separates the username and password into different screens to make it easier and safer for you to log in. When you first see the username screen, you only need to think about entering your name or email, which is simple. Once you do that and hit "next," the second screen asks for your password. This way, it helps you focus on one thing at a time, and it also makes it harder for bad people to steal your information because they need both pieces to get in. It's like having a special door that needs two keys instead of one!

title: how are cured meats made? What makes them edible?
text: Cured meats are made by using special tricks to keep the meat from going bad and to make it taste yummy! First, people take fresh meat, like pork or beef, and they rub it with salt. Salt helps to take out the water from the meat, and when there's less water, bad germs can't grow as easily. Sometimes, they also add spices or sugar to make it taste better. After that, the meat can be left to sit for a while, sometimes for days or even months! This helps to give it a strong flavor. Some cured meats are also dried in the air or smoked to make them extra tasty. When the curing is done, the meat is safe to eat because the salt and the drying help keep it fresh, and it can be eaten on its own or used in sandwiches and other foods!

title: Can everyone theoretically have the same standard of living as people in first world countries?
text: Okay, imagine the world is like a big cake, and some people get really big slices while others get tiny crumbs. In first world countries, people usually have lots of yummy cake – good houses, nice schools, and healthy food. If everyone in the world wanted to have the same amount of cake, we would need to figure out how to share it better. It’s like if we all worked together to bake a bigger cake and make sure everyone gets a nice slice. But it’s tricky because some people have more resources and help than others, like different tools and ingredients. So, while it’s possible to think about everyone having the same nice things, it would take a lot of teamwork and sharing to make it happen!

title: Why are southern Californian counties so large compared to northern Californian counties?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons. In Southern California, the crayons are really big and have lots of space to spread out, so each county can be super huge, like a giant drawing. But in Northern California, it's like having a smaller box with lots of little crayons packed together, so the counties are smaller because there's less room for them to spread out. Also, a long time ago, some places in Southern California were made to be bigger because they had more open land, while Northern California has more mountains and forests, which means there’s less space for big counties. So, it’s like how some kids have big toy boxes and some have little ones!

title: How do autopsies work?
text: An autopsy is like a special detective job for doctors that helps them find out why someone got very sick or passed away. Imagine if you have a toy that broke and you want to know why. You would look inside it to see what happened, right? Well, doctors do something similar with a person's body. They gently open it up to look at all the different parts, like the heart, lungs, and brain, to see if something was wrong. They take notes and sometimes pictures so they can tell the person’s family what they found out. This helps everyone understand what happened and can even help doctors learn how to keep other people healthy. So, an autopsy is like solving a mystery about what happened to someone’s body!

title: Why is California such a magnet for people?
text: California is like a big, shiny toy that lots of people want to play with! It has beautiful beaches where you can build sandcastles, tall mountains for climbing and looking at pretty views, and fun places like Disneyland where you can meet your favorite characters. The weather is usually nice and sunny, which makes it great for playing outside. Plus, there are many jobs and opportunities for people to do what they love, like acting, making technology, or growing food. So, just like how you might want to go to a park with lots of fun things to do, lots of people want to go to California because it has so many exciting things!

title: What are "out-of-body" experiences, and how do they work?
text: Okay, imagine you’re playing a video game where your character can fly around and see everything from above. An out-of-body experience is kind of like that! Some people say they feel like they’re floating above their own body and can see themselves from a different place, like a superhero watching from the sky. This can happen when someone is really sleepy, dreaming, or sometimes when they're feeling very scared or sick. Scientists think it might be your brain playing tricks or mixing up feelings, like when you spin around really fast and then stop and feel wobbly. It’s like your brain is saying, "Whoa, let’s look at things from a different angle!" But don’t worry, you’re still in your body, just having a cool adventure in your mind!

title: When there's a salmonella outbreak, how is it determined which single product is responsible?
text: When there's a salmonella outbreak, scientists and health experts work like detectives to figure out which food made people sick. First, they collect samples from people who got sick and test them to see if they have salmonella. Then, they ask those people what they ate recently. They look for patterns, like if many of them ate the same type of food, like eggs or chicken. They also test the food from stores or farms to see if it has salmonella too. If they find the same type of salmonella in the sick people and the food, they can say that food is likely the one that made people sick. It's a bit like solving a puzzle to make sure everyone stays safe!

title: why when you put a wooden spoon across a pot does the water not boil over?
text: When you put a wooden spoon across a pot of boiling water, it helps stop the water from bubbling over and making a big mess. The bubbles that form when water gets hot are like little balloons of steam that want to rise to the top. When those bubbles hit the wooden spoon, they can't go over it easily, so they pop or get squished down instead of spilling out. It’s like the spoon is a little barrier that calms the bubbles down, making sure they don’t overflow. So, the spoon helps keep the water in the pot where it belongs!

title: Where did the thought of mice loving cheese come from?
text: A long time ago, people noticed that mice liked to eat lots of different foods, including cheese. Cheese is soft, smelly, and easy for mice to nibble on, kind of like how we enjoy sweets! So, over time, stories, cartoons, and movies started to show mice munching on cheese because it was fun and made people laugh. Since everyone saw that, they just assumed all mice loved cheese, even though they eat other things too, like grains and fruits! So, the idea stuck, and now we think of mice and cheese as best buddies!

title: How can we recycle urine and get it back to clean drinking water?
text: Okay, so imagine your body is like a big water bottle, and when you drink, your body uses the water and makes a special kind of juice called urine. Now, we can actually clean that juice and turn it back into safe drinking water! First, we collect the urine, like putting it in a big bucket. Then, we use special machines to filter out all the yucky stuff, just like using a coffee filter to make your juice super clean. After that, we can use things like heat and special chemicals to kill any tiny germs that might be hiding in there. Finally, we end up with clean water that’s safe to drink again! It’s like magic, but it’s really just science helping us reuse water instead of wasting it!

title: Why is war not a war crime? Where do you draw the line? Torture? Mustard gas? Why not killing? Nukes?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are playing a game, and sometimes the game gets really serious, and you start arguing or fighting. In the real world, countries sometimes have big fights called wars, and they can be really messy and sad. Now, not every fight is a 'bad' fight, but there are rules to help keep things fair and safe, just like in your games. War itself isn't a crime because sometimes countries think they need to fight to protect themselves or their friends, but there are rules about how to fight. For example, using things like torture (hurting people to get information) or mustard gas (a really bad chemical that can hurt lots of people) is against the rules because those things hurt innocent people and can make things worse. So, when we talk about lines, it’s about what’s fair and what’s not. Killing in a war can be complicated because sometimes soldiers are just doing their jobs, but if someone hurts people in a really mean way, like using nuclear bombs that can destroy whole cities, that's where we say, "Whoa, that’s not okay!" There are big groups of people, like the United Nations, that try to make sure everyone knows the rules and that we do our best to be nice, even in tough times. So, while war itself isn’t a crime, there are definitely parts of it that can be, and we have to keep working to make sure the rules are followed.

title: Why do most current-gen games on consoles require you to wait until it's fully installed, while last-gen games could be played immediately?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of LEGO blocks. A long time ago, when you got a new LEGO set, you could start playing with it right away because the pieces were all in one place and easy to find. This is like last-gen games on consoles – they were simpler and you could jump in and start having fun without waiting. But now, with current-gen games, they are like a really big and complicated LEGO set with lots of pieces that need to be sorted and put together before you can play. This means the console needs to put everything in the right spot so it works better and looks prettier, which takes a little time. So, you have to wait until it's all set up before you can start playing, but when it's ready, the game is way more fun and exciting!

title: Dentists, HOW do you manage to pull out my molar without leaving a gaping hole to heal in its place?
text: Okay, so when a dentist pulls out a tooth, like a molar, they are really careful. First, they make your mouth numb so you don’t feel any pain. Then, they use special tools to loosen the tooth and take it out. After the tooth is gone, they clean the area really well. Instead of just leaving a big hole, your body helps heal it! Your gums will close up and fill in the space where the tooth was. It’s like when you scrape your knee and it gets better over time. So, even though it might look like a hole at first, your body is super good at fixing itself!

title: How does terminal Velocity work?
text: Okay, so imagine you're jumping off a really tall slide with a big fluffy parachute! When you first jump, you go super fast because gravity is pulling you down, like when you drop a ball. But as you fall, the air pushes against you, trying to slow you down, like when you hold your hand out of the window of a car. At first, you're going faster and faster, but then something cool happens! The air pushes back so much that it matches how hard gravity is pulling you down. When that happens, you stop speeding up and just fall at a steady speed. This steady speed is called "terminal velocity." It’s like when you're riding your bike really fast and then find a speed that feels just right. So, you don't keep getting faster; you just keep falling at that same speed until you land!

title: why do speeds given to me by speed tests never actually accurately represent my internet speed?
text: Okay, so imagine your internet is like a big water slide at a water park. When you go down the slide, you can go really fast, but sometimes there are kids in the way or the water isn't flowing well, and you slow down. When you do a speed test, it’s like going down the slide when no one is in the way and the water is perfect, so you see how fast you can really go. But when you’re using the internet for things like watching videos or playing games, there might be other kids (like other people using the internet) or the water (like how good the connection is) isn’t flowing perfectly, so it feels slower. That’s why the speed test says you can go really fast, but sometimes it feels like you're crawling.

title: How do we connect a prosthetic limb so that it can "feel"?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy robot arm that you can control with a remote. A prosthetic limb is like a robot arm for people who lost their arm or leg, but instead of a remote, we use special technology to help it move. To make the prosthetic feel things, doctors and scientists put tiny sensors in it, kind of like the ones in your tablet that sense when you touch the screen. These sensors can send messages to the brain, telling it what the prosthetic is touching, like if it’s holding something soft or hard. So, when someone uses their prosthetic arm, it can send signals that help their brain understand what it feels like, just like how your fingers feel things and send messages to your brain!

title: Why does hot water freeze faster than cold water?
text: Okay, imagine you have two cups of water, one with hot water and one with cold water. At first, you might think the cold water should freeze faster because it’s already cold, right? But sometimes, the hot water can freeze faster! This is called the "Mpemba effect." It happens because hot water can make little bits of water vapor that float away, and when the water loses some of that steam, it can cool down more quickly. Also, when hot water is in the freezer, it might make the air around it colder, which helps it freeze faster too. So, sometimes, the hot water can be sneaky and freeze quicker than the cold water!

title: why we don't have a world wide credibility rating for every public figure/platform ?
text: Imagine if every time you met someone new, there was a big chart that said how trustworthy they are. That would be cool, right? But making a chart like that for everyone, like all the famous people and companies, is really hard. People have different opinions about what's good or bad, and some things can change really fast. Plus, there's a lot of arguing about what makes someone trustworthy. If we had a chart, it might just confuse everyone, and some people might be unfairly rated. So, instead, we try to listen to many voices and check facts ourselves to decide who we can trust.

title: What are crazy long math equations used for, and what do they solve?
text: Crazy long math equations are like really big puzzles that help us figure things out in the world. Imagine you have a giant box of toys, and you want to know how many toys you have in total if you add more toys or take some away. Those long equations help scientists, engineers, and even computer programmers answer tricky questions, like how to build a bridge so it doesn’t fall down, or how to send a rocket to space. They use these equations to solve problems about how things move, how they work, and how to make things better. Even though they look super complicated, they're just a way to show all the tiny steps needed to find the answer to a big question!

title: Why do hot steam (from hot springs/hot shower) feel suffocating even though water is made of hydrogen and oxygen molecules?
text: Okay, imagine when you take a hot shower, the hot water makes lots of tiny little water droplets that float in the air, and we call that steam. When the steam is really hot, it warms up the air around you, and it can make it feel hard to breathe because the air is thick with water. Your lungs want to take in fresh air that has oxygen in it, but the hot steam is like a big blanket of warm water that makes it feel like there’s not enough space for that fresh air. It’s kind of like when you wrap yourself in a big, fluffy blanket and you feel cozy but also a little squished! So, even though steam is made of the same stuff as water (hydrogen and oxygen), when it’s hot and everywhere, it can make it tricky to breathe comfortably.

title: why do some shots get injected into the vein while others are put into muscles?
text: Okay, so imagine your body is like a big city with roads that help things move around. When you get a shot, it's like sending a delivery truck with medicine to different places in your body. Some shots go into your veins, which are like the fast highways that can quickly take the medicine all over the city. These shots are usually for things that need to work really fast, like when you're really sick or need help right away. Other shots go into your muscles, which are like side streets. They don’t work as fast, but they can deliver the medicine slowly over time, like making sure you have a steady supply of goodies. So, depending on how quickly the medicine needs to work and how it needs to spread, the doctor decides where to send it!

title: Why do cities offer free internet? What's the catch?
text: Cities offer free internet because they want to help people connect and use the internet for things like school, work, and finding information. It's like giving everyone a toy to play with that helps them learn and stay in touch with friends and family. The catch is that sometimes the internet might not be super fast or might not work everywhere, and the city could collect information about how people use it. They do this to improve the service or to make sure everyone is safe online. So, it’s like sharing a big playground: it’s fun for everyone, but you have to follow some rules to keep it nice!

title: Why does everyone hate Breitbart news?
text: Some people don't like Breitbart News because they think it tells stories in a way that makes some groups of people look bad or makes things seem worse than they really are. It’s a bit like if a friend only told you the bad things about another friend, you might not like them very much either. Some folks believe that Breitbart doesn't always share the whole truth or is very one-sided, which can make people upset. So, just like how we all have different favorite TV shows, people have different feelings about news and some really don’t like Breitbart!

title: if multiplying by Zero returns Zero, why does division by Zero return 'undefined'?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big bag of candies, and you want to share them with your friends. If you have 10 candies and you want to share them with 5 friends, you can give each friend 2 candies. That’s like dividing! But what if you want to share those candies with 0 friends? Well, that doesn’t really make sense because you can’t share candies with nobody! It’s like asking how many candies each friend would get if there are no friends at all. So, we say dividing by zero is "undefined," which means it doesn't have a clear answer, just like you can't really share candies if there are no friends to share with. But if you multiply something by zero, like 5 times 0, you end up with nothing because you’re taking away all the candies, which is why you get zero!

title: Why are even numbered houses on one side of the road and odd on the other?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are lining up to play a game, and you decide to stand on one side of the playground while your friends stand on the other side. To keep things neat and easy to count, you all decide that the kids on your side will have even numbers, like 2, 4, 6, and so on, while the kids on the other side will have odd numbers, like 1, 3, 5, and so on. This way, when someone wants to find a house, they can look for even numbers on one side and odd numbers on the other side, making it super easy to find where to go! It's just a simple way to organize things so everything is clear and tidy.

title: What exactly happened to make Julian Assange and Wikileaks go from loved to hated?
text: Okay, so imagine there's a superhero named Julian Assange who found a way to share secret information that people wanted to know, like what some big, powerful people were doing behind closed doors. At first, a lot of people thought he was really cool because he was helping them see the truth and making the world a better place. But then, some of the secrets he shared ended up hurting people or putting them in danger, like showing where soldiers were or how some countries were doing things that made people scared. So, instead of being a hero, some people started to see him as a troublemaker who was causing problems instead of helping. That’s why he went from being loved to being hated by some people.

title: How did humans get to North America if life started in Africa and there were no boats back then?
text: A long, long time ago, when the earth was different, there was a big piece of land called a "land bridge" that connected Asia and North America. This land bridge was made because the ocean was much lower back then, so people could walk across it like a giant pathway. These people, who we call early humans, traveled from Asia to North America by walking over this land bridge. They didn’t have boats yet, but they were really good at moving around and exploring new places! So, they walked and found new homes in North America.

title: how do touch screens work that they can be manipulated by my hand, but not accidentally by my sleeve?
text: Touch screens work like magic! They have a special layer that can feel when something touches it, like your finger but not your sleeve. When you touch the screen with your finger, it sends a little signal to the computer inside to say, "Hey, someone is touching me!" This is because your finger is warm and can make a special kind of electricity that the screen can understand. But when your sleeve brushes against it, there isn't enough warmth or the right kind of touch, so the screen knows it's not your finger and doesn't do anything. It's like a game where only the right players can touch the ball!

title: What does the mandelbrot set have to do with chaos theory?
text: Okay, imagine you have a magic drawing tool that can create really cool and twisty shapes. The Mandelbrot set is one of those shapes, and it looks super complicated, but it comes from a simple math rule. Now, chaos theory is all about how small changes can make big differences, like how a tiny butterfly flapping its wings can change the weather far away. When you zoom in on the Mandelbrot set, you see that even though it looks wild and crazy, it has patterns and rules hiding in there. So, the Mandelbrot set shows us how some things can seem really messy and chaotic, but they still follow special rules that we can understand, just like how the world works in surprising ways!

title: What is the logic behind the terms "Low Skill Floor" and "High Skill Floor"?
text: Okay, imagine you're learning to ride a bike. A "low skill floor" means that it's really easy to start riding the bike, even if you don't know how to do tricks or ride super fast. You can just hop on and go! But a "high skill floor" means you need to learn a lot of tricky stuff before you can really ride well or do cool tricks. So, when people say "low skill floor," they mean it's easy to start and have fun right away, while "high skill floor" means you have to practice a lot before you can be really good at it.

title: When you hear of political protests around the world why is it so often "student protesters" who are involved?
text: Okay, so imagine you’re in school and you really care about something, like your favorite game or ice cream. Students are usually younger and have lots of energy and ideas, and they want to make things better. They often feel like they can change things because they’re not as worried about jobs or families yet, so they can stand up for what they believe in. Also, schools are places where students talk and think about what’s fair or unfair, so they learn about things like rights and justice. When something makes them really upset, like unfair rules or treatment, they come together, like a big team, to tell everyone, “Hey, we want things to be different!” That’s why you see a lot of students in protests—they care and they want to make their voices heard!

title: Why cant we go beyond Planck units?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a tiny ruler that measures really, really small things, like the tiniest toys you can think of! Now, the Planck units are like the smallest measurements we can use in the whole universe, kind of like the smallest toy you can make. When we try to measure things smaller than that, it gets super weird and confusing, like trying to see what's inside a toy without opening it! At this tiny size, the rules of physics that we know start to break down, and we don't really understand what's happening anymore. So, it's like there's a limit to how small we can go, and beyond that, it's a big mystery!

title: If I have a source of light like a flashlight in a dark room, how can I see things that, when the light beam bounces off them, it doesn't reach my eyes?
text: Okay, imagine you're in a dark room with a flashlight. When you turn on the flashlight, it shines light all around. The light hits things like walls, toys, or furniture, and bounces off them. That's how you can see those things. But if the light bounces off something and goes in a different direction, like away from you, you won't see it because the light didn't come to your eyes. To see those things, you need to change where the flashlight is pointing so the light can bounce off the stuff and come back to you. Or you can move around and let the light hit the things from a different angle. It's like playing a game of tag, where the light has to "tag" the stuff so you can see it!

title: Why does hot chocolate have a drinkability window of about 20 seconds; whereas, it seems like coffee stays the perfect temperature for much much longer?
text: Okay, so imagine you have two cups: one with hot chocolate and one with coffee. When you first make them, they're super hot! But hot chocolate is usually thicker and creamier because it has milk and sugar in it, which means it can cool down faster than coffee. It's like when you have a warm cookie and it cools down quicker than a big heavy cake. So, after you pour hot chocolate, it feels really nice to drink for just a little bit, like 20 seconds, before it gets too cold or maybe too hot! Coffee, on the other hand, is usually just black and thinner, so it can stay warm longer. It's like a little race: the hot chocolate cools down quickly, but the coffee takes its time to cool off. That's why you have to sip hot chocolate fast, but coffee can keep you cozy for a while!

title: Why do you feel both warm and cold when having the common cold?
text: When you have a cold, your body is like a superhero fighting off bad germs. Sometimes, it gets really warm, like when you wrap up in a blanket, because it's trying to kill the germs. This makes you feel hot, like you have a fever. But then, your body might also feel cold because it’s working so hard and using up energy, or because you’re not moving around much. So, you might need a blanket when you feel cold, but you also feel warm inside. It's like your body is having a little battle and doesn't know whether to wear a sweater or take it off!

title: Why is there so much USA currency (quarters/nickels/dimes) circulating in Canada and can it be exchanged at a bank for Canadian change with the exchange rate? Why or why not?
text: Okay, so you know how sometimes you get a toy or candy from a friend, and then you share it with other friends? Well, money can be a bit like that too! A lot of people in Canada have US coins like quarters, nickels, and dimes because sometimes they visit the United States or get them from friends who do. It's like sharing toys across the border! Now, about trading those US coins for Canadian money at a bank: banks usually don’t take US coins because they only want the money that belongs to Canada. It's a bit like a game where each country has its own special toys or money, and they don’t mix them up. So, if you have US coins, you can spend them in some places that accept them, but you can't just walk into a bank and switch them for Canadian coins.

title: Why do people get red cheeks when something embarrassing happens?
text: When people feel embarrassed, their body gets a little confused and thinks something scary is happening, like a lion is chasing them! So, it sends extra blood to their face to help them be ready to run away. This makes their cheeks turn red, like a bright apple. It’s just their body’s way of showing they feel shy or embarrassed, kind of like how you might feel nervous before speaking in front of your class!

title: Why do some animals eyes reflect light, but humans eyes don't?
text: Some animals have a special layer behind their eyes called the tapetum lucidum. This layer helps them see better in the dark by bouncing light back through their eyes so they can catch more of it. When light hits their eyes, it reflects back, making their eyes shine bright, especially at night. Humans don’t have this layer, so our eyes don’t shine in the dark like some animals do. Instead, our eyes just absorb the light, which is why they don’t reflect it the same way!

title: How can carshows like roadkill build vehicles with literally no exhausts while at the same time brands like Volkswagen are being sued over air pollution because of their cars?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a toy car that goes really fast, but it makes a loud noise and puffs out a lot of smoke when it goes. That’s kind of like regular cars that have engines and make pollution. Now, at special events like car shows, sometimes people build really cool and different cars that can be super fast but don’t have the same parts that make noise and smoke, like exhaust pipes. They might use electric power or special engines that don’t create pollution. On the other hand, companies like Volkswagen made cars that didn’t pass the rules for keeping the air clean, kind of like if you broke a rule at school and got in trouble. So, while cool car shows can have fun cars without pollution, some big companies have to follow strict rules to keep the air clean, and when they don’t, they can get in big trouble!

title: Why and how does a panic attack occur? Is it describable by words?
text: A panic attack is like when your body gets really scared for no reason, even if there's nothing scary around. Imagine you're playing with your toys and suddenly, your heart starts beating super fast, like a drum, and you feel like you can't breathe well. It's kind of like when you see a big spider and feel really scared, but this happens even when there's no spider! Your brain gets confused and thinks something bad is happening, so it sends messages to your body that make you feel all jumbled up and shaky. Sometimes, it can happen because you're feeling really worried about something, but sometimes it's just a surprise! It’s hard to explain in words because it feels like a big storm of feelings inside you, but it usually goes away after a little while. If it happens a lot, talking to a grown-up or a doctor can help, just like how you would tell someone if you fell and got hurt!

title: Why are there certain sounds men and women make sexually that aren't made in any other situation?
text: Okay, so when people are feeling really happy or excited, like when they’re having fun or playing, they sometimes make special sounds that show how they feel. When it comes to adults and being romantic, the sounds they make are different because those feelings are super strong and special, like a big hug for your heart! These sounds can help people connect with each other, just like when you laugh or squeal when something tickles you. So, men and women make these unique sounds during special moments because it helps express their feelings in a way that words sometimes can’t. It's like their own secret way of saying, "I really like this!"

title: Why are eggs in the US refrigerated in grocery stores, but in other places (for example, Panama) eggs are simply on a room-temp shelf?
text: Okay, so eggs are like little treasure chests that hold baby chickens! In the US, we keep them in the fridge because we wash them really well to make sure they're super clean. But washing takes off a special protective layer that helps keep bad germs away, so the fridge helps keep them safe and fresh. In other places like Panama, they don’t wash the eggs as much, so that protective layer stays on, and it helps keep the eggs safe at room temperature. So, in the US, we chill our eggs to keep them safe, while in other places, they can stay out because they still have their special shield!

title: How is a piece of software like "Scan/Check Disk" able to fix a piece of hardware being your "Hard Drive"? What is going on behind the scenes here and why can't the OS just fix these errors on-the-fly?
text: Okay, imagine your hard drive is like a big toy box where you keep all your toys (which are your files and programs). Sometimes, if you play too rough or if the toy box gets a little messy, some toys might get stuck or broken. Now, "Scan/Check Disk" is like a friendly helper that comes in to clean up and fix your toy box. It looks inside to find any toys that are out of place or broken and helps put them back where they belong or fixes them. The reason the computer can't just fix these problems while you're playing is because it's super busy doing other things, like running games and showing you pictures. So, it needs to take a break and let the helper do the cleaning and fixing when you're not using it. That's why you run "Scan/Check Disk" at a different time, so it can focus on making sure everything in your toy box is nice and tidy without distractions!

title: Why are serif fonts "easier to read in long paragraphs of text?"
text: Serif fonts are like having little shoes on the letters! They have tiny lines or decorations at the ends of the letters, which help your eyes know where one letter ends and another begins. When you read a long paragraph, these little shoes help guide your eyes along the lines, making it easier to keep track of where you are. It's like following a path in a park; the little shoes help create a clear path for your eyes, so you don’t get lost and can read more easily!

title: what happens if you leave the microwave door open and it's turned on?
text: If you leave the microwave door open and it's turned on, it's like trying to use a toy that doesn’t work right. Microwaves are made to cook food by bouncing invisible waves around inside, but they’re super careful, so they won’t let those waves out if the door is open. That means if you try to turn it on with the door open, it just won’t work at all! It’s kind of a safety feature to keep you safe from those invisible waves, so you don’t get hurt. So, if you ever see a microwave, make sure the door is closed before you try to use it!

title: Why does ice melt when we sprinkle salt on it?
text: When we sprinkle salt on ice, it helps the ice to melt faster. You see, ice is made of frozen water, and when it's really cold, the water molecules are all stuck together tightly. But when we add salt, it mixes with the water that’s on the surface of the ice. This salt water is colder than the ice, so it makes it harder for the ice to stay frozen. The salt also makes it so that the water needs to be even colder to freeze again. So, instead of staying solid, the ice starts to turn back into water, and that’s why we see it melting!

title: Why are movies so quiet during normal dialogue, yet so loud during music score or action scenes?
text: Movies are sometimes quiet during talking because they want you to really listen to the words the characters are saying. It's like when you're having a whispering conversation with a friend, you pay more attention. But when there's music or action, like explosions or car chases, they make it loud to make you feel excited and to grab your attention, like a big surprise! It's all about making you feel different emotions at different times. So, they play with the sound to help tell the story better and make it more fun to watch!

title: If alcohol and marijuana are both believed to increase the dopamine in your brain, why do they produce different highs?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a big party where dopamine is the happy music that makes everyone dance. When you drink alcohol, it’s like turning up the music really loud, making everyone feel relaxed and a bit silly, like a fun party where people laugh and talk a lot. But when you smoke marijuana, it’s more like changing the music to something slow and chill, which makes people feel calm and thoughtful, like lying on the grass and looking at the clouds. So even though both alcohol and marijuana make the happy music (dopamine) play, they change the vibe of the party in different ways, making you feel differently.

title: Why do tears come out of your eyes when you yawn?
text: When you yawn, your body is trying to take a big breath to get more air and wake up! Sometimes, when you do that big stretch and open your mouth wide, it can make your eyes feel a little funny. Your eyes have tiny glands that make tears to keep them wet and comfy. So, when you yawn, these glands might make a bit more tears than usual, and that’s why you see some tears coming out. It's like your eyes are just a little surprised by the big yawn!

title: What's the "phantom" feeling we experience when we take a ring or bracelet we've been wearing for a long time off?
text: Okay, imagine you've been wearing a bracelet or ring for a long time, like it's a special friend that always hugs your finger or wrist. When you take it off, your finger or wrist can feel like it’s still being hugged, even though there’s nothing there anymore. This is called a "phantom" feeling. It happens because your brain is used to feeling the ring or bracelet there, and sometimes it gets a bit confused and thinks it’s still there, even when it’s not! It’s like if you take off your shoes and your feet still feel like they’re wearing them for a little while. Your brain just needs a tiny bit of time to remember that the ring or bracelet is gone!

title: How does far infrared radiation help humans heal/recover?
text: Okay, imagine you’re wrapped in a cozy blanket that feels warm and nice. Far infrared radiation is like that cozy warmth, but it comes from special lights instead of a blanket. When this warmth touches your skin, it goes deep inside your body and helps your muscles and other parts feel better. It’s like giving your body a gentle hug that makes it feel relaxed and helps it fix itself when you’re hurt or tired. This special warmth can also help with things like sore muscles or stiff joints, making it easier for you to move and play again! So, far infrared radiation is like a warm friend that helps your body heal and feel good!

title: Why do most international fast food chains offer some menu items that are exclusive to one region/country, and are not available at all participating locations worldwide?
text: Okay, imagine you have a favorite toy that you love to play with, but your friend in another country has a different toy that they think is super cool. Fast food restaurants are like that! They want to make yummy food that people in different places will really like. So, they look at what people in each country enjoy eating. For example, in one country, people might love spicy chicken, while in another, they might really like a special kind of fish. The restaurant wants to make everyone happy, so they create unique menu items just for that place. It's like having special surprises that only some friends get to enjoy!

title: How does a game like Call of Duty have practically no online delay at all while when playing a game like NBA 2K17, multiplayer modes experience about a full second of delay between when the button is pressed and when the game responds?
text: Okay, so imagine you’re playing catch with a friend. If you throw the ball and your friend catches it right away, that feels really good and fast, like in Call of Duty. But if you throw the ball and your friend takes a long time to catch it, that feels slow, like in NBA 2K17. In video games, the “ball” is the buttons you press, and how fast your friend (the game) responds depends on how well it can talk to the other players online. Call of Duty is like a super fast game of catch because it uses special tricks to send the button presses really quickly and smoothly to everyone playing. It also has a way of making sure everyone sees the same action at almost the same time. NBA 2K17 might take longer because it has more things to think about, like all the players moving and things happening at once, which can slow down how fast it reacts to your button presses. So, it’s all about how quickly the game can send and receive messages between players and how much stuff it has to deal with at the same time!

title: Why are all our emotions stronger at night than during the day?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy that lights up when you press a button. During the day, there are lots of other toys and people around, so it’s hard to see that light shining brightly. But at night, when it’s dark and quiet, that same toy lights up really bright and you can see it much better. Our feelings are like that toy; during the day, we’re busy and distracted, so we don’t notice our emotions as much. But at night, when things are quieter and we have time to think, our feelings can seem super strong and bright, just like the light from the toy.

title: How does Chemotherapy work?
text: Chemotherapy is like using a special medicine to fight bad guys in your body, which are called cancer cells. Imagine your body is a big city, and sometimes, the bad guys (cancer cells) start to take over and cause trouble. Chemotherapy is like sending in a police force (the medicine) to find those bad guys and make them go away. It works by attacking the fast-growing bad guys, but sometimes it can also accidentally hurt some of the good guys (healthy cells) in your city, like the ones that help you feel strong and happy. So, while it can help get rid of the bad guys, it can also make you feel a little sick for a while. But the goal is to make the city safe again!

title: How do meteorologists estimate the inches of expected snowfall in a given area?
text: Meteorologists, who are people that study the weather, use special tools and information to guess how much snow will fall in a place. First, they look at big weather maps and see where clouds are and how cold it is. They also use machines called radar that can see where the snow is coming from and how heavy it is. They gather information from weather stations that are set up all over the place, which tell them about temperature and wind. Then, they look at how much snow has fallen in the past during similar weather. All of this helps them make a good guess about how many inches of snow will land on the ground, so people can be prepared with their warm clothes and shovels!

title: Why do people stop using 5 point harness safety belts in cars once they're older?
text: Okay, imagine you're in a car and your mom or dad puts you in a special seat with a 5-point harness, which is like a superhero belt that keeps you really safe. It has five straps to hold you snug, so you don’t bounce around if the car stops suddenly. But as you get bigger and older, you don’t need that superhero belt anymore because your body is big enough to use a regular seat belt, which goes across your lap and over your shoulder. It's like how you outgrow your baby clothes! The regular seat belt is still safe for bigger kids and adults, but it’s just different and easier to use. So, when kids grow up, they switch from the superhero belt to the regular seat belt because it fits them better and keeps them safe too!

title: why is gold so much more valuable than silver?
text: Gold is more valuable than silver for a few reasons. First, there’s less gold in the world than silver, kind of like how there are fewer rare toys than common ones, so people want gold more because it’s harder to find. Second, gold doesn’t rust or get old like some other metals, which means it looks shiny and pretty forever, making it special. Also, people have been using gold for a long, long time to make jewelry and trade things, so it has a history that makes people trust it. So, because it’s rare, shiny, and has a long history, people think gold is worth more than silver!

title: How can cheese age so long and be edible, but then go bad after a little bit in the fridge?
text: Okay, imagine cheese is like a special toy that can be played with in different ways. When cheese is made, it can be kept in a special way that lets it age slowly, like letting a toy sit in a safe box for a long time. During this time, good bacteria and flavors help the cheese become really yummy, just like how a toy can get cooler when you play with it a lot over time. But when you open a cheese package and put it in the fridge, it's like taking the toy out of the box and letting dust and germs from the air get on it. If you don't eat the cheese or keep it covered, those germs can make it go bad, just like a toy that gets dirty and doesn't work well anymore. So, cheese can last a long time when it’s taken care of, but it can spoil quickly if it’s not!

title: Why can phones make such a loud noise for an amber alert? Why can't they normally go this loud?
text: Okay, imagine your phone is like a little toy that can make sounds, like music or your favorite game noises. Normally, it keeps the volume at a nice level so it doesn't hurt your ears. But when there's an amber alert, which is a super important message about a missing person, the people who made your phone want to make sure you hear it no matter what. So, they make the phone go really loud, like when a fire truck goes "wee-woo!" This way, even if you're playing or if it's quiet, you can hear it and help keep someone safe. It's like a special superhero sound to get everyone’s attention! After the alert is done, it goes back to the regular, softer sounds so it doesn't bother you all the time.

title: How does a digital timetable display know how far away a train is?
text: Okay, imagine the train is like a toy car on a big track, and there's a special friend called a computer that keeps track of where the car is. The train has a little gadget inside called a GPS, which is like a treasure map that tells it where it is on the track. The train sends this information back to the computer. Then, the computer uses this information to figure out how far away the train is from the station and tells the digital timetable to show you when the train will arrive. So, when you see the timetable, it's like magic, but really it's just the computer talking to the train!

title: Why do distant lights appear to "shimmer"?
text: Distant lights look like they're shimmering because of the air between you and the lights. Imagine the air is like a big blanket that moves around. When the air gets hot or cold, it can change how light travels through it, like how a bumpy road makes a car shake. So, when you look at a light far away, the wiggly air makes the light look like it's dancing or shimmering, even though the light itself is not moving at all! It's just the air playing tricks on your eyes.

title: Why do some foods taste better when reheated than they do when fresh from the oven? (like Lasagne)
text: Some foods, like lasagna, can taste better when you reheat them because the flavors have time to mix together more after they cool down. When you first cook it, all the yummy tastes are there, but they might not be blended perfectly. When you put it in the fridge and then heat it up later, the ingredients get cozy with each other, and that makes the flavors stronger and tastier. Plus, when you reheat it, the cheese can get nice and melty again, which is super delicious! So, sometimes waiting a little bit can make your food even yummier!

title: How does the Magic Eraser work?
text: A Magic Eraser is like a special sponge that helps clean things really well! Imagine if you had a super soft, fluffy sponge that could make dirt and marks disappear. When you rub the Magic Eraser on a wall or a table, it picks up the dirt and stains like a superhero catching bad guys! It works because it’s made of tiny, tiny bits that are really good at grabbing onto stuff. So when you scrub with it, the dirt sticks to the sponge and leaves the surface nice and clean, just like magic!

title: Why do the drawstrings on sweaters and hoodies always try to come out of the hoods when they are run through a washer and dryer?
text: Okay, so you know how when you pull on the drawstrings of your hoodie, they get tighter and sometimes they poke out a little? Well, when you put your hoodie in the washing machine and it spins around really fast, everything inside gets tossed around a lot, kind of like a roller coaster! The drawstrings are like little noodles that can wiggle around. The spinning makes them want to slip out of their spots, and since they’re not tied down, they just pop out of the hood! It's like if you had a toy car on a slide, and when you push it, it zooms down and flies off the end. That's why when you take your hoodie out, the drawstrings are sometimes halfway out or all the way out!

title: How do TV advertisements earn so much money when it seems like no one pays attention to them?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of yummy cookies, and you want to share them with your friends. You know your friends love cookies, so you invite them over for a snack. While they’re munching on those cookies, you also tell them about a new toy that just came out, hoping they’ll want it! Now, even if some of your friends are busy talking or playing, there are still a few who are listening and thinking, “Wow, I want that toy!” This is kind of like TV ads. Even if people seem to ignore them, lots of people are still watching TV. Companies pay to show their ads because they believe that some of those viewers will see the ad and decide to buy their product, just like some of your friends might want cookies and toys! So, even if it looks like nobody is paying attention, a lot of people still notice and that helps the companies make money.

title: Why is it brighter outside at night went it is snowing?
text: When it snows, the snowflakes are like tiny little mirrors that catch and bounce light all around. So, if there’s a streetlight or the moon shining, the snow makes that light spread everywhere. This is why it can feel brighter outside at night when it's snowing, even though it's dark. The snow helps the light to shine more, just like when you shine a flashlight on a shiny surface and it lights up the whole room!

title: What's going on in Mexico right now with the raising of gas prices and other amenities? Why are people looting stores and pissed off?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a lemonade stand, and one day you decide to raise the price of your lemonade because the lemons cost more. Now, your friends who love your lemonade are upset because they have to pay more money to buy it. In Mexico, the price of gas, which is like the fuel that helps cars go vroom-vroom, has been going up, just like your lemonade price. When things like gas and food get more expensive, people start to worry that they won't have enough money to buy what they need. Some people get really mad and feel like they’re not being treated fairly, so they might do things like take stuff from stores without paying, which is called looting. It's not a good thing, because it can hurt the people who own the stores and make everyone feel unsafe. So, people are upset because they want to be able to afford the things they need, and when prices go up, it makes life harder for them.

title: Why can you hear the voices in the apartment above you so easily, but not the voices in the apartment below you?
text: Okay, imagine your apartment is like a big cake with different layers. The people above you are on the layer right over yours, so when they talk, their voices come down to you like a little slide. Sound travels easily through the air and the walls, kind of like how you can hear a friend calling you from the next room. But the people below you are on a layer underneath, and the sound has to go through more stuff to reach you, like the floor and the ground. It’s like trying to hear someone talking while you’re standing on a big pile of pillows; it makes it harder to hear them. So, that’s why you hear the voices from above better than the ones from below!

title: Why does orange juice from Tropicana taste different from Simply Orange if they're both 100% Orange Juice?

title: Why are most circuitboards green? Does it make a difference if its any other color?
text: Most circuit boards are green because they use a special kind of plastic called epoxy, which is green when it’s made. This color helps to hide tiny mistakes, like little scratches or bumps, that can happen when making the boards. It also makes it easier for people to see the tiny wires and parts on the board. Other colors can be used, like blue or red, but they don’t really change how the circuit board works. It’s mostly just about looks and making it easier to see everything!

title: What is that clicking sound in your ears every time you swallow something?
text: That clicking sound you hear in your ears when you swallow is like a little door opening and closing! Inside your ears, there's a tiny tube called the Eustachian tube that helps balance the air pressure inside your ears. When you swallow, the muscles around that tube make it open so air can come in or out. Sometimes, when it opens, it makes a little click or pop sound, just like when you crack your knuckles! It’s perfectly normal and just means your ears are doing their job.

title: Why do bread items always heat up so quickly in the microwave compared to any other food item?
text: Bread items heat up quickly in the microwave because they are mostly made of air and water, which are both good at absorbing the microwave's energy. When you put bread in the microwave, the microwaves make the water molecules move really fast, and that makes the bread warm up quickly. Other foods might be denser or have more solid parts, which means they don’t absorb the microwaves as easily, so they take longer to heat up. It's like if you were trying to warm up a sponge versus a rock; the sponge gets warm fast because it can soak up the heat, but the rock takes longer because it’s solid and doesn’t soak up the heat as well.

title: Can someone explain why a Government deficit is made out to be so bad, especially since it appears that most Governments are running them?
text: Okay, imagine you have a piggy bank where you keep your allowance money. If you spend more money than you have in your piggy bank, you have a "deficit," which means you're borrowing money to buy things, like toys or candy. Now, if you keep borrowing money, one day you might not be able to pay it back, and then you can't buy anything at all! That's why having a deficit can be seen as bad for governments too. They sometimes spend more than they earn, like when they pay for schools, roads, or hospitals, and if they do this too much, people get worried they won't be able to pay back what they owe. But sometimes, it's okay for governments to have a deficit, especially if they are using that money to help everyone, like building new parks or fixing old stuff. It's like using your allowance to buy a really cool toy that will make you happy for a long time, but you still have to be careful not to keep borrowing too much!

title: Why does Greenland have more Ice than Iceland and vice-versa? [Other]

title: How did banks keep track of legitimate withdrawals before the electronic age?
text: Before computers and fancy machines, banks used paper and pencils to keep track of money. They would then write down that you took some out, so everyone knew how much was left. It was like keeping score in a game, but instead of points, it was all about money!

title: What causes that "sinking heart" feeling when extremely sad?

title: Why does a weak am/fm radio signal result in a consistent static/fuzzy sound while a weak satellite radio signal results in intermittent high quality sound?
text: Okay, imagine you’re trying to listen to your favorite song on the radio. If the message is clear, you get to hear the whole song really well, but if the signal gets really weak, it’s like your friend is sending you bits of the song that sometimes cut in and out. So, satellite radio can still sound good when it works, but if it can’t find a strong signal, it just stops sending any sound at all!

title: - Why is it that after a night out drinking people often wake up relatively early and refreshed?

title: How do scientists predict, down to the exact degree, what the temperature will be for the next week?

title: What causes a beer belly?
text: A beer belly happens when someone drinks a lot of beer and eats too much food, especially food that is not very healthy. title: Why does Pi have infinite digits?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really, really long string of numbers, like a piece of yarn that goes on and on forever. title: when a person has an electric shock that travels along their nerves, does the electricity travel the same way as normal nervous signals?

title: Why do movies and TV shows use old phones and odd-looking texting and computer platforms?

title: How does a plan detect that missiles have been 'locked on'? What does this mean?
text: Okay! So, imagine you have a toy that can see things really far away, like a telescope. When the plane's tools say, "I see the missile and I can follow it," that's when we say it has "locked on." This helps the plane know exactly where the missile is so it can do something about it, like shoot it down or move out of the way. title: Why the definition of an integer is independent of the number base used?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big box of crayons, and you can count them in different ways. If you count using your fingers, you might say you have 10 fingers, so you can count to 10. But if you use a different way, like putting your crayons in groups of 5, you can also count them and say you have 2 groups of 5 crayons. An integer is just a whole number, like 1, 2, or 3, and it doesn’t change no matter how you count it or what counting system you use. So whether you say it in your fingers, in groups of crayons, or in a special counting system called a "base," the number itself stays the same. That's why the definition of an integer is the same no matter what number base you use!

title: How do waterfalls freeze?

title: Why do erasers fail to fully remove pencil marks?

title: How does eating lots of fatty/fried foods lead to sore throat?

title: What is that 'beep' sound that submarines make in movies ?

title: What is that whistling sound when an old TV turns on?

title: Why and how you need to clean out your ears?
text: You need to clean out your ears because sometimes dirt and wax can build up inside and make it hard for you to hear or feel comfortable. title: Why do clothes hung up to dry take over 8 hours to dry when my swimsuit is completely dry an hour after I leave the pool?

title: Why are some allergies so common, like peanuts?

title: what's the difference between brown sugar and "normal" sugar?

title: Why do some people/countries deny the Armenian Genocide?

title: How could the universe not be infinite?

title: how do countries repay their debts ?

title: What happens to particle movement below absolute zero?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a toy that you can make go really fast or really slow. But scientists found a way to make some special particles behave differently. title: If I call a friend from far away, how does my call find it's way to his/her cellphone?
text: Okay, imagine you want to send a letter to your friend who lives far away. Instead of using a letter, you use your voice, and instead of a mailbox, you use a special system called a cell phone network. When you call your friend, your voice gets turned into tiny bits of information that travel super fast through invisible pathways, like magic roads in the air. These roads are made of signals that go from your phone to a big tower nearby. That tower then sends the signals to another tower closer to your friend, and finally, it reaches your friend's phone. When your friend answers, their phone does the same thing in reverse, turning their voice into signals that travel back to you. So, it’s like sending a speedy message through the air until it gets to your friend!

title: What's a byte (gigabyte, megabyte) made of and how big is it?
text: Okay, imagine a byte is like a little box that can hold a tiny piece of information, like a letter or a number. Now, if you have 1,000 of those little boxes, you have a bigger box called a kilobyte, which can hold more letters or numbers. If you have 1,000 kilobytes, that makes a megabyte, which can hold even more! Then, if you get 1,000 megabytes, you have a gigabyte, which is super big and can hold lots of pictures, songs, or games. So, think of it like stacking boxes: a byte is a small box, a kilobyte is a thousand little boxes, a megabyte is a thousand of those bigger boxes, and a gigabyte is a thousand of the biggest boxes!

title: Why do you get a headache the day after a night of crying?
text: When you cry a lot, your body gets really tired and your eyes can get puffy from all the tears. title: Why do far away things appear small?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy car and you're holding it really close to your face. It looks big, right? Now, if you move that toy car far away, it looks smaller, even though it's the same size! It's kind of like how if you see a big building from really far away, it looks tiny, but when you get close, it looks super big! So, the farther away something is, the smaller it looks!

title: How were scientists able to film and capture the stages of childbirth before/during the 90's?
text: Before the 90s, scientists and doctors used special cameras and tools to film childbirth. title: How is the US Intellegence community fundamentally different from when they were so confident of WMD in Iraq?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and you think there might be a really cool toy inside that box. title: Why do we feel extremely disoriented after waking up from a nap, but not as much from a regular night's sleep?
text: When you take a nap, your brain can wake up from a part of sleep that makes you feel really sleepy and fuzzy, like when you're in a deep dream. This is called "sleep inertia," and it can make you feel confused and wobbly for a little while. But when you sleep at night for a longer time, your body gets to finish all the sleep stages, so when you wake up in the morning, you usually feel more awake and ready to go. It's like if you were playing a game and had to stop right in the middle; you'd feel a bit lost. But if you finish the game, you know exactly what to do next!

title: How much does illegal immigration really affect the United States?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big box of crayons that you share with your friends. Now, some kids might come in and take crayons without asking, which is a bit like illegal immigration.
