title: Why are car manufacturers doing away with traditional gear shifts?
text: Car manufacturers are getting rid of traditional gear shifts because they want to make driving easier and more fun! Instead of having to move a stick or press buttons to change gears, many new cars use something called automatic transmissions. This means the car can change gears all by itself, just like magic! It helps people focus on steering and enjoying the ride instead of worrying about shifting gears. Plus, some new electric cars don’t even need gears at all, making them super simple to drive. So, it’s all about making driving safer and simpler for everyone!

title: What is Bose Einstein Condensate and how does it look like?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of super tiny, invisible marbles, and these marbles are all bouncing around really fast. Now, if you make everything super, super cold, like colder than anything you can find in your freezer, those marbles start to slow down and huddle together. When they get cold enough, they stop bouncing around and act like one big marble instead of lots of little ones. This special group of marbles is called a Bose-Einstein Condensate, or BEC for short. It's like when a bunch of friends hold hands and move together instead of running around separately. You can’t really see a BEC because it’s made of tiny particles, but scientists can create it in special labs and it helps them learn more about how tiny things in the universe work!

title: Why is it sleep deprivation can sometimes be euphoric and other times it's wretched? Is there a way to influence it one way or the other?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a fun balloon that needs air to float. When you don't get enough sleep, sometimes that balloon feels super light and happy, like it's floating high, making you giggle and feel silly. That's the euphoric part! But other times, if your balloon doesn't have enough air for too long, it gets heavy and sad, making you cranky and tired. That’s the wretched part! Whether you feel happy or sad when you're sleepy can depend on lots of things, like how long you've been awake, what you did that day, or even how you feel inside. If you want to feel more happy when you're sleepy, it can help to be in a fun place with friends, eat yummy snacks, or listen to happy music. But remember, getting enough sleep is super important to keep your balloon floating just right!

title: Why does toast bread keep all the cheese in while normal bread lets the cheese ooze out?
text: Okay, imagine toast bread is like a cozy little blanket that hugs the cheese really tight, while normal bread is more like a soft, fluffy pillow that can't hold things in as well. When you toast the bread, it gets a little crunchy and firm on the outside, which helps keep the cheese from slipping out. But with regular bread, it's soft and squishy, so when you put cheese on it, the cheese can just slide away and ooze out. So, toast bread is better at keeping the cheese safe and snug!

title: Does my breastmilk have healthier properties if I eat healthier food?
text: Yes, it does! When you eat healthy foods like fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, your body makes better breastmilk for your baby. Think of your body like a chef in a kitchen. If the chef uses fresh, good ingredients, the food (or breastmilk, in this case) will be tasty and good for you! So, when you eat healthy, your breastmilk can have more vitamins and nutrients that help your baby grow strong and be healthy too. It's like giving your baby a special superpower drink made from the best ingredients!

title: how do muscles push?
text: Muscles can't push like a person pushes a toy, but they can pull! When you want to move something, your brain tells your muscles to get tight and shorten, which pulls on your bones. Imagine a rubber band: when you pull it, it gets smaller, and that helps it pull something closer. Your muscles work like rubber bands – they pull to make you move, but they can’t push by themselves. So, when you see someone pushing something, they are actually using their muscles to pull their bones and body in a way that makes it look like they are pushing!

title: If I'm about to starve to death but food was present at the very last moment, would it save me?
text: Yes, if you are really, really hungry and about to starve, finding food at the last moment can help you! Your body needs food to get energy and stay alive, just like a car needs gas to drive. If you eat something before your body runs out of energy completely, it can give you the strength to feel better and start getting healthy again. But, if someone is super weak or hasn't eaten for a long time, they might need to eat a little bit at a time, like tiny bites, so their tummy can get used to it again. So, finding food can be a lifesaver!

title: Why do people who haven't had a great education and on low incomes vote for parties on the right when most of the time their polices are against them?
text: Okay! So, imagine you have a box of crayons, and some crayons are really bright and colorful, while others are a bit dull. Sometimes, people choose the bright crayons because they think they will make their drawing look better, even if those crayons don’t really help them color the picture they want. People who might not have lots of money or education sometimes feel like the right-side parties are the bright crayons. They might believe those parties will help them feel safer or stronger, even if the rules they make don’t help them much. It could be because they trust what those parties say or because they think they’ll get help in a different way, like getting jobs or feeling proud. So, even if it seems strange, they choose the bright crayons because they think it will make their lives better.

title: Why does honey never expire?
text: Honey never expires because it has special properties that keep it safe to eat for a really long time. First, bees make honey by taking nectar from flowers and mixing it with their special tummy juice, which helps turn it into honey. Then, they fan their wings to dry it out, making it thick and sticky. This low moisture means that bacteria and mold can't grow in it. Also, honey is very acidic, which makes it even harder for germs to live there. When you keep honey in a sealed container and away from water, it can last for thousands of years! So, it's like a super yummy treasure that doesn't go bad!

title: Why do car stereo remotes exist?
text: Car stereo remotes exist so that people can control the music in their car without having to reach over and push buttons on the stereo itself. Imagine you are sitting in the back seat and want to change the song or make it louder; it's hard to reach the front! The remote is like a magic wand that lets you tell the stereo what to do from far away. It makes it easier and safer to enjoy your favorite tunes while driving because the driver can keep their hands on the steering wheel and eyes on the road.

title: why aren't ovens white on the inside? Since black absorbs heat the best, wouldn't that be the worst color?
text: Ovens are usually not white on the inside because white can get really dirty and hard to clean. When you cook, food can splatter and leave marks, and white would show all those stains, making it look messy. Black is often used instead because it helps hide those stains and also helps the oven heat up evenly. Even though black absorbs heat well, the oven is designed to keep the heat inside, so the color doesn’t really matter for cooking. The most important thing is that the oven works well and is easy to clean!

title: What causes the moon to occasionally appear yellow?
text: The moon can look yellow sometimes because of the air between us and the moon. When the moon is low in the sky, like when it's rising or setting, its light has to pass through more air. This air can have dust, pollution, or water in it, which makes the moon's light look more yellow, kind of like how the sun looks orange or red at sunset. So, when you see a yellow moon, it's just the air playing tricks with the light!

title: What do doctors infer from using Stethoscopes? How can they identify what's wrong with us by just hearing us breathe?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big, noisy factory, and it makes lots of sounds when it's working. Doctors use a stethoscope, which is like a special listening tool, to hear the sounds your body makes. When you breathe, your lungs make a whooshy sound, kind of like blowing air through a straw. If the doctor hears clear sounds, it usually means your lungs are healthy, like a clean factory making things right. But if they hear funny noises, like crackles or wheezes, it can mean there’s something not quite right, like a machine that's not working properly. So, by listening carefully to your breathing and heart, doctors can figure out if everything is okay or if you need a little help to feel better!

title: Why do people often want something even more once they know they can't have it?
text: Okay, imagine you really want a shiny red toy, and then someone tells you that you can't have it because it's broken or someone else is playing with it. Suddenly, that toy seems super special and exciting, and you want it even more! This happens because our brains like to think about things we can’t have. It makes them seem extra special, like a treasure! So, when we hear "no," it makes us want it more, just like how you might want ice cream even more when your mom says you can't have it right now!

title: Why does someone ignoring you cause so much pain and anger?
text: When someone ignores you, it's like playing a game and your friend decides to stop playing and walk away. You might feel sad because you want to have fun together, and it feels like they don't care about you. That sadness can turn into anger because you might think, "Why don't they want to play with me?" It’s like feeling left out at a party where all the kids are having fun and you’re sitting alone. Our feelings get hurt because we want to be liked and included, and when someone ignores us, it feels like they’re saying we don’t matter. So, it's normal to feel pain and anger when this happens because we all want to be loved and noticed by our friends!

title: What makes certain foods cancerous?
text: Some foods can be cancerous because they have things in them that can hurt our bodies if we eat too much or too often. For example, some foods have chemicals that can make our cells act funny, which might lead to cancer. Things like burnt meat, processed foods, and lots of sugar can be bad if we eat too much of them. It's like how too much candy can give you a tummy ache; eating too much of these foods can make our bodies not work right. But don’t worry, if we eat a lot of healthy foods like fruits and vegetables, we can help keep our bodies strong and happy!

title: ;What exactly is meant by Bismarckian and machevellian politics. What are good examples of their actions that brought about these terms?
text: Bismarckian and Machiavellian politics are two ways of thinking about how to get what you want in government or leadership. Bismarckian politics comes from a man named Otto von Bismarck, who was a leader in Germany a long time ago. He believed in being smart and using careful plans to unite different parts of Germany and make it strong, even if it meant being a little sneaky sometimes. For example, he tricked other countries into thinking they were friends while secretly preparing for war to make Germany powerful. Machiavellian politics comes from a guy named Niccolò Machiavelli, who wrote a book about how leaders should act. He said it’s okay for leaders to be tricky and do whatever it takes to stay in power, even if it’s not nice. A famous example is when he said it’s better for a leader to be feared than loved, because fear can keep people in line. So, in short, Bismarckian politics is about smart planning and sometimes tricking others for a strong country, while Machiavellian politics is about being clever and sometimes mean to keep power.

title: What causes the difference in intelligence between persons?
text: Okay, so imagine that your brain is like a big sponge that soaks up information and ideas. Some people might have sponges that are really big and can soak up a lot, while others have smaller sponges that soak up less. This difference can happen because of many reasons, like how we grow up, the things we learn, and even how our brains are built. For example, if someone has lots of books to read and people to talk to, their sponge gets filled up with more knowledge. Also, some people might have special ways their brains work that help them solve problems faster or remember things better. So, intelligence is like having different-sized sponges and different ways of soaking up the world around us!

title: Why does sticking out your tongue help you concentrate?
text: Sticking out your tongue when you’re trying to concentrate is a bit like how some people might chew on a pencil or tap their foot. It’s something your body does to help focus your brain. When you stick out your tongue, it’s like giving your brain a little extra boost of energy or a way to get rid of extra wiggly feelings. It's a funny habit that some people do because it helps them think better, kind of like how a superhero might have a special move that helps them be strong! So, it’s just one way our bodies can help our brains do their best work!

title: How do we figure out the exact weight of protons, neutrons, and electron?
text: Okay, imagine you have a super fancy scale that can weigh really tiny things, like protons, neutrons, and electrons, which are parts of an atom, kind of like how you have different Lego pieces to build something. Scientists use special tools and experiments to measure how heavy each piece is. For protons and neutrons, they can use a big machine called a particle accelerator that smashes tiny particles together to see how heavy they are. They learned that protons and neutrons are almost the same weight, but neutrons are a tiny bit heavier. Electrons are much lighter than both of them, like a feather compared to a big rock! So, by using these tools and doing a lot of tests, scientists figured out the exact weights of these tiny particles.

title: why do light bulbs only seem to ever go out when turning them on instead of while they're already on?
text: Light bulbs can kind of be like people who get really tired when they wake up. When you turn on a light bulb, it has to work really hard all of a sudden, and sometimes that’s too much for it. It might have a little crack or something inside that makes it weak, and when you turn it on, that’s when it finally gives up and stops working. When the bulb is already on, it’s like it’s already awake, so it usually doesn’t have that big shock. So, it’s not that they can’t break while they’re on, it’s just that they often wait until you turn them on to say, “I can’t do this anymore!”

title: Why do millennials earn 20% less than baby boomers did at same stage of life?
text: Okay, so imagine you have two groups of friends. One group is called the Baby Boomers, and the other group is called the Millennials. The Baby Boomers got their first jobs when things were a bit different, like when candy bars cost less and houses were cheaper. They could save money and buy nice things more easily. Now, the Millennials are getting jobs when everything costs more, like rent and food. So, even if they work just as hard, they end up getting paid less compared to what the Baby Boomers made when they were the same age. It's like if you had to buy the same toy but the price went up a lot, so you have to use more of your allowance to get it. That’s why Millennials earn less money compared to Baby Boomers at the same point in their lives.

title: How do internet startups get a big user base before they are well known?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really cool lemonade stand, but nobody knows about it yet. To get lots of people to come and try your lemonade, you might do a few special things. First, you could give away free samples so people can taste how yummy it is! Then, you could ask your friends to tell their friends about it, like a big game of telephone, so more people hear about your stand. Some lemonade stands even make colorful signs or use silly songs to grab attention. Internet startups do similar things! They might share their cool ideas on social media, make fun videos, or even ask people to invite their friends to join. This way, even before everyone knows about them, they can start having lots of users who love what they offer!

title: Why do we stretch?
text: We stretch to keep our muscles and bodies happy and healthy! Imagine your muscles are like rubber bands. If you don't use them or stretch them, they can get tight and stiff, just like a rubber band that hasn't been played with. When you stretch, you're making those rubber bands longer and looser, which helps you move better and feel good. Stretching can also help you not get hurt when you're playing or exercising, just like how you warm up before running around. Plus, stretching can feel really nice and make you feel relaxed, kind of like a big hug for your muscles!

title: Why can you hold water, or any liquid, in a straw by placing your finger over the opening?
text: When you put your finger over the top of a straw filled with liquid, you’re creating a seal that keeps the liquid from falling out. Think of it like a magic trick! The liquid wants to fall down because of gravity, which is like an invisible hand pulling it down. But when you cover the top with your finger, you stop air from getting in and that air pressure helps hold the liquid up inside the straw. It’s like the liquid is sticking to the straw, and your finger is helping keep it in there. When you take your finger off, the air rushes in, and the liquid goes down!

title: When you see stories like, "12 year old invents cheap alternative to a significant medical/military/household product", what actually happened? Were they receiving some uncredited assistance or are they actually just child geniuses working alone after school?
text: When you see stories about a 12-year-old who invented something cool, it usually means they had a lot of help from adults, like teachers or family, who guided them in their project. Sometimes these kids have a big idea and work really hard on it, but they often don’t do it all by themselves. They might use special tools or ideas that adults helped them learn about. It’s kind of like when you build a really awesome Lego tower with some help from your mom or dad; you get to say you made it, but they helped you along the way! So, while these kids are super smart and creative, they usually have some grown-ups cheering them on and helping them out.

title: How do people calculate the energy, fat, protein, carbohydrates, and sodium?
text: Okay! Imagine you have a big box of LEGO, and each type of LEGO piece is different like energy, fat, protein, carbohydrates, and sodium. To know how many of each piece you have, you can open the box and count them. In food, we do something similar! People look at the ingredients and use special tools or rules to find out how much energy (like how much power the food gives you), fat (the squishy stuff), protein (the building blocks for muscles), carbohydrates (the yummy sugar and bread stuff), and sodium (the salty part) is in the food. They often read labels on food packages that tell them these numbers, or they can use a calculator that helps them figure it out. So, just like counting LEGO pieces, they count these different parts to know what’s in the food!

title: Why do we puke when we get too dizzy?
text: When you feel really dizzy, it’s like your brain is getting mixed signals, like if you were trying to listen to two songs at the same time. Sometimes, this confusion makes your tummy feel upset, like it’s on a roller coaster. When your tummy feels bad, it might want to get rid of what’s inside to feel better, so it makes you puke. It's your body's way of saying, "I don't like this feeling," and it tries to help you feel okay again!

title: Why arent SSDs and SD cards the same size even though a lot of them can hold the same amount?
text: Okay, so imagine you have two different types of toy boxes. One toy box is really small and flat, like a piece of paper, and that’s like an SD card. The other toy box is a bit bigger and thicker, like a book, and that’s like an SSD. Even though both toy boxes can hold a lot of toys (which is like how both can store a lot of data), they are made for different purposes. The SD card is meant to be tiny so it can fit in small places, like in a camera or a phone. The SSD is bigger because it can hold even more toys and is usually used in computers. So, they can hold the same amount of stuff, but they come in different shapes and sizes because they are made to fit different kinds of things!

title: How come that when you go to bed at 11PM you have a hard time to leave your bed at 7AM, but when you go to bed at 3AM you dont have any problems waking up at 11AM while you had the same hours of sleep?
text: When you go to bed at 11PM and wake up at 7AM, your body is still in a sleepy time because you didn't get enough rest in that time, even if you slept for 8 hours. Your body likes to follow a special clock called a "circadian rhythm" that helps it know when to sleep and when to wake up. Going to bed late at 3AM means your body is still following that clock, but you've shifted it to a later time. So when you wake up at 11AM after going to bed late, your body is more ready to get up because it's been sleeping at the time it thinks is right for you! It feels easier because your body is more awake and ready to go at that new time.

title: What's the point of auto manufacturers working with their rivals to create identical vehicles, ie: Ford Escape/Mazda Tribute, Pontiac Vibe/Toyota Matrix?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friend both want to build a cool toy car, but it takes a lot of time and effort to make one from scratch. So instead, you decide to work together and share your toys and ideas. This way, you can both build your toy cars faster and make them even better! Auto manufacturers do something similar. When companies like Ford and Mazda team up to create similar cars, they can save money and time because they share the work. They can use the same parts and designs, which helps them make cars that are safe and fun to drive without having to do everything by themselves. Plus, it gives people more choices because even if the cars look a bit alike, they might have different features or styles, just like how your toy cars can have different colors or stickers!

title: What do bees actually do with the honey they make? Surely they don't eat that much being so small.
text: Bees make honey to store food for themselves, especially for when it's cold and flowers aren't blooming. Even though bees are small, they need energy to fly and work, just like you need food to play and grow! When they collect nectar from flowers, they turn it into honey, which is sweet and gives them lots of energy. They keep the honey in their hive, and it helps them survive when there's no fresh food around. So, honey is like their special snack that they can eat later when they need it!

title: How does swallowing upside down work?
text: Swallowing upside down is a bit like pouring a drink from a cup that’s turned over! When you swallow, your throat muscles help push the food or drink down to your tummy. Even if you’re upside down, those muscles still work the same way; they just have to push the food a little differently. So, if you’re hanging from a tree or lying on your head, your body still knows how to move the food down because it’s smart and can adapt! It’s kind of like how you can still walk even if you wear silly shoes; your body just figures it out!

title: Why, when we are falling from a height, is it our first instinct to swing our arms in a circular motion?
text: When we start to fall, our body feels scared and wants to do something to help us. Swinging our arms in a circular motion might feel like we are trying to grab onto something or change our direction, just like how a bird flaps its wings to stay in the air. It’s like our body's way of trying to find balance and control, even if it’s just instinct. Our arms moving around also helps us feel a little better because we might think it could help us land safely, even if it really doesn’t. It’s just our brain trying to protect us!

title: Why is peanut butter only available in jars and not wider containers like hummus?
text: Peanut butter is usually in jars because it's thick and sticky, which makes it hard to scoop out of wider containers without making a big mess. Jars are also easy to close, so the peanut butter stays fresh and yummy for a long time. If it were in a wider container, it might get hard to reach the peanut butter at the bottom, and it could spill everywhere when you try to get some out. Plus, jars are really good for keeping things safe and protected!

title: Why do car manufacturers put out such futuristic looking cars at auto shows, knowing that they would never put those cars into production?
text: Car manufacturers create those cool, futuristic-looking cars at auto shows to show off their ideas and dreams for the future! It's like when you draw a picture of a spaceship or a robot that doesn't exist yet. They want to inspire people and get them excited about what cars might look like someday. Sometimes, they also use these designs to test how people feel about new things, like shapes and colors. Even if they don't make those exact cars, they might take some ideas from them to make real cars later. So, it’s a way to play and imagine what could be possible!

title: Why does water make whisky taste different?
text: Water makes whisky taste different because it changes how the flavors mix together! Imagine you have a box of crayons. If you use one crayon, like blue, you get one color. But if you add a little bit of white crayon to it, the blue becomes lighter and you can see different shades. When you add water to whisky, it spreads out the flavors and lets you taste new things that you might not notice when it's just the whisky by itself. So, adding water can help you find more yummy tastes in your drink!

title: Why do we feel cold when our body is hot during fever?
text: When you have a fever, your body is trying to fight off germs that make you sick, like a superhero getting ready for a battle! To help you get better, your brain tells your body to heat up, kind of like turning up the thermostat in your house. But sometimes, your body gets so hot that it feels really uncomfortable, like being too warm in a thick blanket. So, even though your body is warm, you might feel cold because your brain is also trying to cool you down a little. It’s like when you go outside on a hot day and feel chilly if a breeze comes by. Your body is just trying to find the right balance to make you feel better!

title: Why does vanilla taste delicious in food but disgusting when you try it straight up?
text: Vanilla tastes yummy in food because it mixes well with other flavors, like sugar and cream, making everything sweet and nice! When you eat vanilla straight from the bottle, it’s really strong and kind of weird because it's not mixed with anything else. It’s like if you had a piece of candy and then just ate a spoonful of sugar – the sugar alone is too much and doesn’t taste as good by itself! So, vanilla needs friends like chocolate or cake to make it taste really good!

title: How and why is mental illness hereditary?
text: Okay, so imagine your brain is like a big box of crayons, and each crayon is a different part of how you think and feel. Some families have certain colors that come from their parents, like blue for sadness or red for anger. When a baby is born, they get a mix of crayons from their mom and dad, which means they might also get some of those feelings and ways of thinking. This is what we mean by hereditary, like getting traits from your family. Now, mental illness can happen when the way those crayons are mixed up isn't quite right, making it harder for someone to feel happy or calm. So, if a parent has a mental illness, the child might also have some of those same crayons in their box, making it more likely they could feel similar things too. But remember, it's not just about the crayons; things like how you grow up and what happens in your life also play a big part!

title: What is the difference between a poison, a toxin, and a venom?
text: Okay, imagine you have three different kinds of bad stuff that can make you feel sick! A poison is something that can make you sick if you eat it, drink it, or touch it. For example, some plants are poisons because if you chew on their leaves, you can get really sick. A toxin is like a special kind of poison that comes from living things, like certain bacteria or mushrooms. It’s made by them and can still make you sick, just like a poison. Now, venom is a little different! Venom is a special kind of toxin that some animals, like snakes or spiders, use to hurt other animals. They have to bite or sting you to give you the venom, which is like a sneaky way to make you sick! So remember: poison is bad stuff you can touch or eat, toxins are poisons made by living things, and venom is poison that animals use to attack by biting or stinging!

title: How can your body (40, 50 or 60 years later) "remember" that you are immune to virus like chickenpox?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a superhero team that fights off bad guys, like viruses. When you get chickenpox, your superhero team learns how to defeat that bad guy really well. They make special cards, called antibodies, that remember how to fight chickenpox if it tries to come back. Even if it's many years later, like when you're 40, 50, or 60, those superhero cards are still in your body, ready to spring into action if chickenpox shows up again. That's why you usually don't get chickenpox again – your body’s superhero team remembers how to beat it!

title: Why are advertisement on the Internet that are scams not against the law?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a lemonade stand, and someone tries to trick you into buying fake lemons that don’t make any lemonade. That’s not nice, right? In real life, there are laws to protect people from being tricked, but the Internet is really big and a little messy! Sometimes, it’s hard for the people who make the laws to catch all the bad guys who make fake ads. They have to figure out if the ad is really trying to trick people or if it’s just a silly mistake. Plus, different countries have different rules, so what’s a scam in one place might not be in another. But many people work hard to make the Internet safer, like telling you to be careful and not click on things that look weird!

title: What makes some people run so much faster than others?
text: Some people can run faster than others because of a few reasons. First, their muscles might be stronger or built differently, which helps them push off the ground harder and go faster. Second, some people practice running a lot, so they get really good at it, just like how you get better at riding your bike the more you do it. Also, some people are taller or have longer legs, which can help them take bigger steps. Finally, some folks just have a body that is made for running, like a cheetah is made for running fast in the wild. So, it’s a mix of practice, body type, and strength that helps people run at different speeds.

title: How is it possible for a diet soda to have zero calories?
text: Okay, imagine you have a drink that tastes really sweet, like soda, but it doesn't have any sugar in it. Instead, diet soda uses special things called "artificial sweeteners," which are like tiny magic sprinkles that make it taste sweet without adding any calories. Calories are like little energy pieces that come from food, especially sugar, but these magic sprinkles are so much sweeter than sugar that you only need a tiny bit, which means they don't add any energy pieces at all. So, when you drink diet soda, it tastes yummy and sweet, but it doesn't give your body any extra energy pieces, or calories, making it a "zero-calorie" drink!

title: How does the sum of the in infinite arithmetic sequence "1+2+3+4..." equal -1/12?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really, really long line of toys: one toy, then two toys, then three toys, and so on, forever. If you try to add them all up, you get a really big number, right? But mathematicians found a special way to look at this that seems a little silly. They say, "What if we play a game with these numbers?" They use something called "advanced math" and "infinity" to change the rules. When they add all those toys in a different way, they find a surprising answer: -1/12! It sounds weird because we don't usually think of adding things together and getting a negative number. But in this special math game, it helps us understand other tricky math problems better. So, it's like a magical number trick that only works if you follow the special math rules!

title: Why, when you experience pain/discomfort, does your face automatically scrunch up, your brow furrow, your mouth frown, etc? And why does it seem to help with the pain?
text: When you feel pain, your body has a little alarm system that goes off to tell you something is wrong, kind of like a fire alarm. So, your face scrunches up and your brow furrows because your body is trying to show how you feel inside, like a little sign saying, "Ouch, that hurts!" This happens automatically because your brain is working really fast to help you react to the pain, like when you touch something hot and pull your hand away quickly. Making those funny faces might help a little bit because it can release some of the tension in your body, almost like stretching after a long day. Plus, when you show how you feel, it can help others understand that you need a hug or some help, which can make you feel better too!

title: I baked cookies today. When dunking them hot out of the oven, any pieces that broke off sank to the bottom of my cup of milk. But later, after they'd cooled, pieces that broke off floated. Why do hot cookies sink and room-temp cookies float?
text: Okay, so imagine cookies are like little boats! When you take them out of the oven, they’re super hot and soft, kind of like a squishy sponge. When they break, the pieces are heavy and can’t help but sink to the bottom of the milk, just like a big rock would sink. But after they cool down, they get a little harder and less squishy. This makes them lighter, like a little toy boat that can float on water. So, when those pieces break off after they’ve cooled, they can float on the milk instead of sinking!

title: If honey is pure sugar, why is it healthy?
text: Honey is sweet like sugar, but it’s not just sugar! It comes from bees, and they make it from flower nectar. When bees make honey, they add some special things that help our bodies. Honey has tiny bits of vitamins, minerals, and even some good stuff that can help us feel better when we’re sick, like when we have a sore throat. So, even though honey is still sweet like sugar, it has extra things that make it a little healthier! But remember, we should still not eat too much of it, just like with regular sugar.

title: Why do so many books have two to three blank pages at the start?
text: Books often have two to three blank pages at the start for a few reasons. First, it helps make sure that the first page with writing is nice and clean, so you don’t accidentally see any messy stuff from when the book was being made. Second, those blank pages give you a little space to write your name or maybe a note about the book, like who it belongs to. Lastly, they help the book open better when you first start reading it, kind of like stretching before running! So, those blank pages are there to help keep everything neat and make it easier for you to enjoy the story!

title: Why do we pay property taxes if we own the house?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy that you really love, and it’s yours, but you still have to share some of your toys with your friends and help keep your playroom nice and clean. Property taxes are like that! When you own a house, it’s your special place, but the money you pay in property taxes helps take care of things that everyone uses, like parks, roads, and schools. It’s like everyone chipping in to make sure our neighborhood is a nice place to live. So even though the house is yours, you help pay for things that everyone can enjoy!

title: How does the fast inverse square root algorithm work?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and you want to know how many toys are in it really quickly. The fast inverse square root is like a super speedy way to figure out how many toys are in a smaller box without counting every single one. In math, when we want to find out how big something is, like the length of a line, we sometimes need to find the square root. The fast inverse square root helps us find something called the "inverse square root," which is like figuring out how big a box would need to be to hold our toys, but in a faster way. It uses some clever tricks with numbers that make it much quicker than just counting or using a regular calculator. So, just like using a magic shortcut to know how many toys you have without opening the box, the fast inverse square root helps computers do math super fast!

title: How does noise canceling work, and can it hurt your hearing by actually adding more sounds and decibels to your ears?
text: Okay, imagine you have a balloon, and when you blow air into it, it makes a big noise, right? Now, think about noise-canceling headphones like a magic balloon that can stop some of that noise! They have special microphones inside that listen to the sounds around you, like when cars go by or people talking. Then, the headphones create a new sound that is the opposite of the noise. It’s like if you made a sound that said, "shh," and it cancels out the loud sound, making things quieter. So, they don’t actually add more noise; they help to take away the bad noise so you can hear your music better. And no, they won’t hurt your ears because they don’t make sounds that are too loud; they just help make the world around you a little calmer!

title: How does the postal service machinery know the correct amount of postage has been put on via stamps? Especially with old postage stamps, or a many small currency stamps.
text: The postal service uses special machines that can read stamps and check if there's enough money on them to send a letter or package. When you put a stamp on an envelope, the machine looks at the stamp and sees its value, which is like a price tag that tells how much it costs to send the mail. For older stamps or many small stamps, the machine can still read them because it uses cameras and computers to look closely at the stamps. If the stamps add up to the right amount of money needed to send the mail, the machine lets it go through. If not, it can stop the mail and let workers know there’s a problem. So, the machines are like little helpers that make sure you paid the right amount to send your letter!

title: How do resale retail stores (ie. Winners, Homesense etc.) work?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy box full of toys that you don’t play with anymore. Instead of just keeping them, you decide to sell them to other kids who might want to play with them. Resale retail stores, like Winners and Homesense, do something similar, but with clothes and home stuff instead of toys. They buy items that are brand new but maybe didn’t sell at other stores or are extra that people returned. Then, they put those items on their shelves and sell them for less money than the original price. This way, people can find good deals and buy nice things without spending too much, and the store can make some money too! It’s like giving those things a second chance to find a home.

title: What is the purpose of tonsils? Many get them removed and the only time I hear of them is when people get tonsillitis
text: Tonsils are like little guards in your throat that help protect you from getting sick. They catch germs and help your body fight them off, kind of like how a superhero catches bad guys! Sometimes, though, they get really tired or sick themselves, which is called tonsillitis. When this happens a lot, some people have to get their tonsils taken out so they don’t keep getting sick. Even if we remove them, our body has other ways to fight off germs, so people can still be healthy without them!

title: why is it ok to watch a sunset, but its not ok to stare at the sun any other time?
text: Okay, so imagine the sun is like a really, really bright flashlight in the sky. When you look at it directly, like when it's shining super bright during the day, it can hurt your eyes because it's too bright, kind of like looking at that flashlight up close. But when the sun is setting, it's like the flashlight is getting dimmer and changing colors, like orange and pink. That makes it easier and safer for your eyes to look at because it's not as bright anymore. So, watching a sunset is like enjoying a pretty picture in the sky, but looking at the sun during the day is like staring at a super bright light that can hurt you!

title: Why is it impossible to decrypt something after it has been encrypted to md5/bcrypt/etc?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special box that can lock up your favorite toy, and when you put the toy inside and lock it, it makes a special secret code that looks really jumbled up. This code is like a puzzle that only the box can understand. MD5 and bcrypt are like different kinds of these special boxes for information instead of toys. When you lock up your toy, you can't just look at the jumbled code and figure out what toy is inside, because it's designed that way! With MD5 and bcrypt, once you lock something away, you can't easily get back the original thing, kind of like how you can't un-jumble the puzzle. Instead, you have to remember how you locked it up so you can check it later, but you can't go backwards and see what was inside again. That's why it's super hard or even impossible to decrypt it!

title: Why do only some people seem to be overly sexual whenever they are drunk?
text: When people drink alcohol, it can make them feel more relaxed and less worried about what others think. Some people might feel extra happy and silly, which can make them want to hug or kiss more. It’s like when you get really excited about a fun game and want to share that joy! But not everyone reacts the same way; some people might feel sleepy or sad instead. It’s just how different bodies and brains work with alcohol. So, when someone seems overly sexual when they’re drunk, it’s just their way of expressing happiness, but everyone has their own way of reacting!

title: What is dry drowning?
text: Dry drowning is when someone has trouble breathing after being in the water, but it happens even when they didn't actually swallow any water. Imagine you go swimming and you accidentally breathe in a little water, like when you go underwater and come up coughing. Sometimes, that can make your throat and lungs feel funny, and they can spasm or close up, which makes it hard to breathe. This can happen even a little while after you get out of the water, so it’s important for grown-ups to keep an eye on kids after swimming, just to make sure they're okay and can breathe properly.

title: Would death by extreme heat or extreme cold be objectively more painful and why?
text: Okay, so think of it like being really, really hot or really, really cold. When it's super hot, it feels like you're getting burned, and that can hurt a lot because it makes your skin feel ouch! But when it's really cold, it feels like your fingers and toes are freezing, and that can hurt too because it makes you feel like you're all numb and tingly. Now, some people say that being really hot can hurt more because it hurts your skin directly and can make you feel dizzy. But being really cold can also be painful because it feels like your body is shutting down and that can be scary. So, both are really painful in their own ways, and it's hard to say which one is worse because everyone feels pain differently. It’s like asking if a bee sting or a scrape on your knee hurts more; it depends on the person!

title: British lawyers and the British legal system - Prosecutors working for private law firms?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and some kids are really good at sharing toys while others are good at keeping things fair. In Britain, lawyers are like those kids. Some lawyers work for the government, kind of like referees in a game, to make sure everyone plays fair and follows the rules. These lawyers are called prosecutors, and they help decide if someone did something wrong and needs to be punished. Now, some lawyers work for private law firms, which are like special clubs where they help people with their problems, but they don't usually play the referee role. Sometimes, private firms can also have lawyers who help with cases like a prosecutor, but it’s less common. So, in Britain, while most prosecutors work for the government, there are some who can help with cases in private firms too, like when a kid from a club steps in to help share toys in a fair way.

title: What are the differences between a condo, townhouse, and apartment?
text: Okay, imagine you have three different types of homes where people live, like three different kinds of ice cream! A condo is like a scoop of ice cream that you own; you have your own little space, and you can do things like paint the walls, but you share some things with your neighbors, like the pool or the yard. A townhouse is like a really tall ice cream cone that is connected to other cones. You own your part, but you might share walls with your neighbors, and sometimes you have a little yard in the back. An apartment is like a bowl of ice cream that you rent; you don’t own it, and the landlord takes care of things like fixing stuff, but you still have your own space and share the building with other people. So, condos and townhouses are more like owning your ice cream, while apartments are like borrowing it!

title: Why are cloth items like towels, rags, etc. tougher to tear when wet?
text: When cloth items like towels or rags get wet, the water gets into the tiny spaces between the fibers, which are the little threads that make up the cloth. This makes the fibers stick together a bit more, kind of like how a wet sponge is harder to tear than a dry one. The water helps hold everything tightly, so it takes more strength to rip the cloth apart when it's wet. Plus, wet fabric can stretch a little instead of just tearing, which helps it stay in one piece. So, wet towels and rags are tougher to tear because the water makes them stronger and stickier!

title: why is Taiwan valuable to China under the "One China" policy? They've been ruled separately for so long, what would the real benefit to controlling it again be?
text: Taiwan is important to China under the "One China" policy because it’s like a puzzle piece that China thinks should fit into its whole picture. Even though Taiwan has been acting like its own country for a long time, China believes that it was always meant to be part of China. If China controlled Taiwan, it would feel stronger and more complete, and it would also help them in many ways. For example, Taiwan is in a really good spot in the ocean, which is great for trade and shipping, like a busy road for boats. Taiwan also makes a lot of important stuff, like computer chips, which are like the brains for lots of cool gadgets. So, by bringing Taiwan back, China thinks it can be more powerful and have more control over important things in the world.

title: What does "±" symbol mean?
text: The "±" symbol means "plus or minus." It's like saying you can have a number that is a little bit bigger or a little bit smaller. For example, if you see "5 ± 2," it means you can have 5 plus 2, which is 7, or 5 minus 2, which is 3. So, it can mean any number between 3 and 7! It's a way to show that something can change a little bit in either direction.

title: Why do most news websites currently have a "Click to expand article"/"Read More" button on mobile?
text: Most news websites have a "Click to expand article" or "Read More" button on mobile because it helps to make the page look cleaner and easier to read. Imagine you have a big book, but instead of showing all the pages at once, you only see a little bit at a time. This way, it's not too messy or confusing. When you click the button, it opens up and shows you the rest of the story, just like flipping to another page in the book. It also helps the website load faster on your phone, so you don’t have to wait a long time to see the news you want.

title: Why do all movies cost the same?
text: Not all movies cost the same, but sometimes they seem like they do because theaters want to make it easy for everyone. Imagine if you went to buy candy, and one type of candy cost a lot more than another. You might get confused! So, theaters usually pick a price that everyone pays for a ticket to keep it simple. Some movies might cost more to make, like big superhero movies, but the theaters want everyone to come and have fun, so they set the price at a level that most people can afford. Also, some special movies might cost a little more on weekends or when they first come out because lots of people want to see them, like a big party! But overall, it’s about making it easy and fun for everyone to enjoy going to the movies!

title: Why/how do we involuntarily scream when we're scared?
text: When something scares us, our body has a little alarm system inside called the "fight or flight" response. It's like a superhero that wakes us up and gets us ready to run away or stand and fight. When this happens, our brain sends a message to our voice box to make a loud noise, like a scream! This happens really quickly, almost like magic, and we don't even have to think about it. It’s just our body's way of saying, “Help! Something is wrong!” and it can also help get the attention of others who might help us. So, when we scream, it's our body's way of reacting to something scary without us having to choose to do it!

title: why is it that when a lot of people talk at once, the sound is multiplied to a point where, a stadium full of people talking quietly to one another, can be louder than just two people screaming?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are in a big room, and everyone is whispering to each other. Even though you’re all being quiet, there are so many of you that the whispers mix together and sound really loud! It’s like when you pour a lot of little drops of water into a bucket; eventually, it fills up and makes a big splash. In a stadium, when lots of people talk at the same time, their voices combine like that, making one big, loud sound. But if just two people are shouting, their voices don’t mix with anyone else’s, so it doesn’t get as loud as all those whispers. So, a bunch of people quietly chatting can sound louder than just two people yelling!

title: Why does it take ~5 seconds to get yourself to pee? Why isn't it instant? Is this an anti leak mechanism?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big water balloon. When you fill it up with water, it gets bigger and bigger. Your body has a special balloon called the bladder that holds all the pee. When the bladder is full, it sends a signal to your brain saying, "Hey, I'm full! Time to go!" But you can't just let the pee out right away because your body has a little door that keeps the pee in until you're ready. So, when you go to the bathroom, it takes a few seconds for your brain to tell that door to open and let the pee out. This helps you make sure you're in the right place, like the bathroom, so you don’t accidentally pee somewhere else! So, it's not really an anti-leak mechanism, but more like a way to make sure everything is ready before you let the pee go.

title: Why is it advisable to block your license plate when sharing a photo of your vehicle?
text: It's a good idea to block your license plate when you share a photo of your car because the license plate is like a name tag for your vehicle. Just like how you wouldn't want strangers to know your name or where you live, sharing your license plate can let people find out who you are or where you park your car. If someone sees your license plate, they could use it to learn things about you or even do bad things. So, covering it up keeps you and your car safer, kind of like how you wear a mask to keep yourself safe!

title: How's it possible to calculate the volume of geometrical bodies ?
text: Calculating the volume of shapes is like figuring out how much space a toy or a box takes up! Each shape has its own special way to find out how big it is inside. For example, if you have a box (called a rectangular prism), you can find the volume by multiplying how long it is, how wide it is, and how tall it is. So, if your box is 2 blocks long, 3 blocks wide, and 4 blocks tall, you do 2 times 3 times 4, which equals 24 blocks! For round shapes, like a ball (called a sphere), there's a different formula, but it’s still about how much space is inside. So, each shape has its own rules like a game, and when you follow those rules, you can find out how much space it has!

title: How do companies like Coca-Cola make money from vending machines and sales located in very rural areas in undeveloped countries?
text: Okay, imagine you have a lemonade stand, and you decide to set it up in a really quiet place where not many people live. Even though there aren’t a lot of customers, you can still make money in a few ways! Companies like Coca-Cola do something similar with vending machines and sales in rural areas. First, they put their vending machines in places where people might want a drink, like near a school or a bus stop. Even if not a lot of people pass by, the ones who do really want a cold drink, so they buy it. Second, they might sell drinks to little shops in those areas. These shops can sell the drinks to people who live nearby. Even if a shop sells just a few drinks a day, it adds up over time. Plus, Coca-Cola tries to keep their drinks priced so people can afford them, which helps them sell more. So, even in quiet places, they make money by being smart about where they put their machines and by working with local shops!

title: What is the difference between being declared clinically dead, and being actually dead?
text: Okay, imagine your toy robot. When you turn it off, it stops moving and making noises, but if you turn it back on, it can still work again. Now, being declared clinically dead is kind of like when the doctor checks your robot and says, “It’s off right now, but maybe we can turn it back on!” They check for things like your heartbeat and breathing. If those are gone, they might say you’re clinically dead, but sometimes people can still come back if the doctor helps them. On the other hand, being actually dead is like when your robot is broken forever and can’t be turned back on. There’s no way to fix it, and it won’t work again. So, clinically dead means there’s a chance to come back, but actually dead means there’s no coming back at all.

title: how do 64kb demos work? How is a video generated from such a small file?
text: Okay, imagine you have a tiny box with just a few toys inside, but you can use your imagination to make a whole big world out of them! A 64kb demo is like that tiny box. It’s a really small computer program that uses clever tricks to show cool graphics and sounds, kind of like a mini movie, using only 64 kilobytes of space, which is super tiny. The people who make these demos are like really smart artists who know how to squeeze a lot of fun into a little bit of space. They use special codes that tell the computer how to draw shapes, colors, and even move things around, making it look amazing! So even though the file is small, it can still create a big, colorful show that feels like a video!

title: How does MSG make food more flavorful and less importantly, colorful?
text: Okay! So, MSG stands for monosodium glutamate, which is like a magic sprinkle that makes food taste yummier! Imagine if you have a bowl of plain soup that tastes a little boring. If you add a tiny bit of MSG, it makes the flavors pop and taste really good, kind of like how adding a little bit of salt makes things better. MSG helps our taste buds on our tongue notice the yummy flavors more, especially in things like meat and vegetables. Now, about colors, MSG doesn’t really change how food looks, but when food tastes better, it can make you feel like it looks better too! So, MSG mainly helps with flavor, not really with color.

title: Why do we feel guilty after masturbating?
text: Sometimes, after we do something like masturbating, we might feel guilty because of what we’ve been taught or what we hear from others. Some people think that it’s not okay to do, like it's a secret we shouldn’t talk about. Our brains can mix up feelings because we know it’s a normal thing many people do, but we might also feel like we're doing something wrong. It's like if you ate a cookie before dinner, and even though it was yummy, you might feel bad because you were told not to. It’s important to remember that it's a natural thing and everyone has feelings about it, but it doesn’t mean you should feel guilty!

title: What is the role/ effect of music in human psyche? Why do some songs make us cry or some make us happy?
text: Music is like a magical language that talks to our feelings. When we listen to a song, it can remind us of special moments, like a happy birthday party or a sad goodbye. This happens because music has different sounds, like happy, bouncy notes that make us want to dance or soft, slow notes that make us feel a bit teary. Our brains are like big, colorful boxes that fill up with feelings when we hear these sounds. Some songs have words that tell stories or feelings we can relate to, and that can make us smile or cry. So, music helps us express and understand our emotions, kind of like how a big hug can make us feel safe and loved!

title: How does "double-jumping" on a trampoline work?
text: Okay, so imagine you're on a trampoline, which is like a big, bouncy bed. When you jump on it, the trampoline pushes you back up into the air. Now, double-jumping happens when you jump again while you're up in the air! It’s like if you were on a swing and you kicked your legs to go higher. So, when you jump the first time and go up, if you quickly push down with your legs again before you land, the trampoline helps you go up even higher! It’s kind of like getting an extra boost or a little bounce from the trampoline while you’re still flying up. But remember, you have to be quick and strong with your legs to make it work!

title: Why is horse racing such a tossup?
text: Horse racing is like a big game where horses run really fast, and sometimes it’s hard to know who will win. Imagine if you and your friends are running a race, but some of you are a little tired, some have new shoes that help you run faster, and some just ate a big lunch and feel slow. In horse racing, the horses are all different, just like you and your friends. Some might be super fast on a nice day, while others might not feel their best. Plus, the track can change, like if it’s wet or dry, which can make it easier or harder for the horses to run. And don’t forget, the jockeys, who are the people riding the horses, can also make a big difference! So with all these things changing all the time, it’s like trying to guess who will win a surprise party! That’s why it can be a tossup!

title: why do we need to constantly change and adjust laws?
text: We need to change and adjust laws because the world changes all the time, just like how you grow up and learn new things! Imagine if your favorite toy got broken, and you needed a new one that works better. Laws help keep everyone safe and happy, so when new problems come up or when we learn better ways to do things, we change the laws to help everyone even more. It’s like fixing the rules of a game if they don’t make sense anymore, so everyone can play fair and have fun!

title: Why are there different versions of Windows? (ie Windows 10 Home, Pro etc)
text: Okay, imagine Windows is like a big toy box, and inside that box, there are different toys for different kids. Some kids like to play with action figures, others like dolls, and some like building blocks. Each version of Windows is like a different set of toys made for different needs. For example, Windows 10 Home is like a toy set for kids who just want to play simple games and do fun stuff like watch videos. Windows 10 Pro is a bigger set with extra toys for kids who need to do more serious things, like school projects or work, so it has tools that help them be more organized and safe. By having different versions, Microsoft can make sure that every kid (or computer user) gets the right toys they need to have fun or get things done!

title: Why do drummers generally cross their arms when playing?
text: Drummers often cross their arms when playing because it helps them reach all the different parts of their drum set better. Imagine if you were trying to grab toys that are spread out all over your room. Sometimes, if you reach across your body, you can get to things easier! So, when drummers cross their arms, it lets them hit the cymbals and drums quickly and smoothly without getting tangled up. It's like a special way to make sure they can make music with all their cool drums!

title: How does part of a company split off into a sperate company?
text: Sometimes, a big company has a part of it that does something different or special. If that part wants to grow on its own or be better at what it does, the big company can let it become its own smaller company. This is called a "spin-off." It’s like if you had a toy that you really liked and decided to give it to your friend so they can play with it on their own. The toy still exists, but now it’s with your friend, and they can take care of it however they want! So, the big company keeps some of the new little company’s stuff, and both can do their own things better.

title: If the unreal engine is one of the most realistic and better looking game engines, why isn't it used more often in video games?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really cool art set with the best paints and brushes that can make the most amazing pictures ever. That’s like Unreal Engine for video games—it can make super realistic and pretty games! But using it is kind of like painting a giant mural on a wall. It takes a lot of time, practice, and effort to make everything look just right. Some game makers want to make games quickly or don’t have a lot of people helping them, so they might choose simpler tools that are easier to use. Also, some games don’t need to look super realistic, like silly cartoon games, so they pick other engines that fit better for what they want to do. So, while Unreal Engine is awesome, it’s not always the best choice for every game!

title: Why does mold grow on "dead" fruits but not on the ones still on the tree?
text: Mold is like tiny little plants that need food to grow. When fruits are still on the tree, they are fresh and healthy, which means they have stuff inside them that keeps mold away. But when fruits fall off the tree or get old, they start to get soft and yucky, which makes them a nice snack for mold. The mold can then grow on them because there's no tree to protect them anymore. So, mold likes to eat the old, "dead" fruits because they are easier to snack on!

title: How come you can restart the heart to start pumping again, but you can't do the same to the brain once activity ceases?
text: Okay, imagine your heart is like a pump that helps move water (which is like blood) around in a big tube (your body). Sometimes, if the pump stops working right, doctors can give it a little jolt of electricity to help it start pumping again, just like giving a toy a little shake to make it work again. Now, your brain is more like a super-complex computer that controls everything you do. If it stops working, it usually means it's not getting enough power or oxygen. If it’s been off for too long, the computer can get broken and won’t turn back on, just like if you left a toy out in the rain. So, while we can sometimes help the pump (heart) get going again, fixing the computer (brain) is much trickier and not always possible.

title: How do game developers secure their code for their game in that way that it simply won't be copied by any other game company/game developer?
text: Game developers use something called "security" to keep their special game code safe, like a treasure chest that holds a secret map. They do this in a few ways! First, they can use something called "encryption," which is like turning their code into a secret language that only they can read. If someone tries to peek, all they see is jumbled letters! Next, they might use "licenses," which are like rules that say, "Hey, you can't take my toys!" This helps protect their game from being copied. They also keep their code private, like hiding a diary under their bed, so only the people who work on the game can see it. Lastly, if someone does take their game without asking, they can tell the grown-ups (like lawyers) to help them get it back. So, all these things help keep their game code safe and sound!

title: How did English become such a prominent language?
text: English became a big deal because a long time ago, a lot of important people spoke it and it traveled around the world. First, there were the British explorers and traders who went to many different countries, and they brought their language with them. Then, when the British Empire grew really big, people in all those places started using English. Later, after the United States became powerful, more people wanted to learn English because it was the language of movies, music, and the internet. So, now English is like a special key that helps people talk to each other all over the world!

title: What was the Mexican Revolution about?
text: The Mexican Revolution was like a big fight in Mexico a long time ago, starting in 1910. Imagine if some people in a big playground felt like the kids who were in charge were not being fair and were taking all the toys and snacks for themselves. So, the kids who felt left out decided to work together and try to change things. They wanted everyone to have a chance to play and share the toys. The fight lasted for about ten years, and many people were involved, including different groups with different ideas about what should happen. In the end, they made some changes to help everyone have a better life, like having more rules to make things fair. So, the Mexican Revolution was all about fighting for fairness and a better life for everyone in Mexico.

title: What did all the billions donated to cancer research over the years achieve?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and you want to find the best way to play with them. When people give money to cancer research, it’s like giving lots of toys to scientists so they can figure out how to make everyone healthier and happier. Over the years, because of all that money, scientists have learned a lot about what makes cancer happen, kind of like discovering the rules of a game. They’ve found new ways to help people get better, just like finding new ways to play with toys. Some people now have better medicines that help them fight cancer, and doctors can find cancer earlier, which is super important! So, all that money has helped make the game of fighting cancer a little better, but there is still more to learn, just like how you can always find new ways to play!

title: Why does color affect heat absorption?
text: Okay, imagine you have two toy cars, one painted white and the other painted black. When you leave them outside in the sun, the black car gets really hot, but the white car stays cooler. This happens because darker colors, like black, absorb more light and heat, just like a sponge soaks up water. Light colors, like white, reflect a lot of light and heat, so they don’t get as hot. So, the color of things can change how much heat they take in from the sun!

title: Why does online banking (transfers, deposits, etc) cease to operate on the weekends? I would think that me transferring money would be entirely automated and does not require any human involvement at all. And even if it does, why not have some people working on the weekend to help out?
text: Okay, imagine that online banking is like a big toy train set. During the week, the train runs all day and delivers toys (money) to everyone who wants them. But on the weekend, the people who help run the train set (the bank workers) take a break, so the train stops. Even though the train is really smart and can go by itself, it still needs the workers to make sure everything is safe and working well. Sometimes, there are also special things that need to be checked or fixed, like cleaning the tracks or counting the toys, and that can only happen when the workers are there. So, that's why online banking takes a little nap on the weekends, but it’s super ready to go again on Monday!

title: Why are USA and Russia still antagonistic against each other in 2017?
text: Okay, imagine two kids on a playground who used to be friends but had a big fight a long time ago. Now, they don’t trust each other and always think the other one is trying to take their toys or be mean. The USA and Russia were friends a long time ago, but then they had a big fight called the Cold War. Even though they don’t fight like in a war anymore, they still don’t trust each other. They argue about things like who gets to play with certain toys (like land and resources) and how to play nice with other kids (like other countries). So, even in 2017, they still act like they’re not friends because they remember the old fight and worry the other might try to be sneaky.

title: Why do we have bad dreams? more specifically; bad recurring dreams?
text: Bad dreams, or nightmares, can happen for a lot of reasons! Sometimes, they come from things we are worried or scared about, like a monster under the bed or a big test at school. Our brain is like a movie theater that plays our thoughts and feelings while we sleep, and sometimes it shows us scary movies! Recurring bad dreams, which are dreams that happen over and over again, can be like a song stuck in your head; your brain might be trying to tell you something important, like you need to feel safe or deal with something that's bothering you. It's like your brain’s way of saying, “Hey, let’s think about this again!” The good news is, talking about your dreams with someone you trust can help make them less scary!

title: Why does ice pressed on salt produce temperatures of - 28°C?
text: Okay, imagine you have ice and some salt. When you put the salt on the ice, it starts to mix with the ice and changes how the ice melts. Normally, ice melts at 0°C, which is just above freezing. But when you add salt, it makes it harder for the ice to stay solid, so it needs to be even colder to melt. This is called freezing point depression. So, instead of melting at 0°C, the ice can keep melting even when it's much colder, like -28°C! It’s kind of like a magic trick where the ice can get super cold because of the salt, and that’s why we can get such low temperatures.

title: Why does animal tissue smell pleasant while cooking but human flesh smells so badly when burnt?
text: When you cook animal meat, like chicken or beef, it releases nice smells that make us feel hungry and happy because it has natural flavors that smell good. This is because of special chemicals in the meat that change when it gets hot, creating yummy smells. Human flesh, on the other hand, has different chemicals and oils in it that don't smell as nice when burned. Instead, they can smell really bad because of how our bodies are made. So, when we cook animal meat, it makes our tummies growl, but burnt human flesh smells awful because of those different chemicals.

title: why do we get itchy?
text: We get itchy because our skin is telling us something is bothering it. Imagine if you had a tiny bug on your arm or if you touched something rough, your skin gets upset and sends a message to your brain saying, "Hey, something's not right here!" So, we feel the itch and we want to scratch it to make it feel better. Sometimes, it can also happen when we get too hot or when we have a rash, which is like a little bump on our skin. Scratching can help for a moment, but it’s better to be careful because scratching too much can make our skin hurt or bleed.

title: Why does microwaving a lit candle create plasma? (Do not try at home)
text: Okay, so imagine a candle is like a tiny campfire with a wick that you light up to make it glow and smell nice. When you put that candle in the microwave, it's like putting it in a big, warm box that makes things super hot really fast. The microwave makes the wax and the wick get so hot that they start to burn, and sometimes they can burn in a special way that makes tiny, glowing bits of gas called plasma. Plasma is like when a balloon is filled with air, but it’s super hot and can glow like lightning! But don’t try this at home because it can be really dangerous and could make a big mess or start a fire!

title: How do Speedometers work?
text: A speedometer is like a special clock in a car that tells you how fast you're going! It works by feeling how fast the wheels are turning. Imagine if you had a toy car with wheels that could spin really fast. The speedometer has a little part inside that counts how many times the wheels go around in a minute. Then, it uses that number to show you a number on the dial, like 20 or 60, which means you're going 20 or 60 miles per hour. So, the faster the wheels turn, the higher the number on the speedometer gets, helping you know if you're going too fast or just right!

title: How does health insurance work at all if everyone needs it?
text: Okay, so imagine you and your friends love playing with toys, but sometimes toys break or get lost. To help everyone, you all put a little bit of your allowance into a big jar every week. This jar is like health insurance. Now, if one of your friends' toys breaks, you can take some money from the jar to help buy a new one. Everyone pays a little bit into the jar, but not everyone uses it all the time. This way, when someone really needs help, there’s enough money in the jar to fix their toy. Health insurance works the same way! Everyone pays a little bit each month, and when someone gets sick or hurt, they can use that money to help pay for their doctor visits or medicine. It’s like a team helping each other out!

title: I often see people refer to the US presidency with titles like "the world's most powerful office." Is this just America jacking itself off or is there actually stock in a statement like this?
text: When people say that being the president of the United States is "the world's most powerful office," they mean that this person has a lot of influence and can make important decisions that can affect not just the U.S., but also other countries around the world. Imagine if you were the boss of a big playground, and you could decide what games to play and how to share toys with everyone. The U.S. president has a similar job, but instead of a playground, it’s about running a whole country and working with other countries too. So, it's not just bragging; it's because the president has a lot of responsibilities that can really change things for many people, both in America and beyond.

title: How do we create "easy" AI in video games?
text: Creating "easy" AI in video games is like making a toy robot that knows how to play a simple game with you, like tag or hide and seek. First, we give the robot some basic rules, like "if you see the player, follow them" or "if you are close, run away." Then, we make sure it can remember where you are, kind of like how you remember where your friend is hiding. We also tell it not to be too smart, so it doesn't always catch you or win too easily; it needs to make mistakes sometimes, like turning the wrong way or getting stuck. Finally, we test it a lot to make sure it’s fun to play with and not too hard, like letting a friend win sometimes so everyone has fun!

title: Why are circuit boards colored green as opposed to other colors?
text: Circuit boards are often green because of a special layer called solder mask that protects the circuits and helps the pieces stick together. The green color comes from a kind of paint that is easy to see, helps stop mistakes when putting things together, and protects the board from getting damaged. While they can be other colors like blue or red, green is just super popular and works really well, so most people use it!

title: How to treat wounds caused by shotguns?
text: If someone gets hurt by a shotgun, it’s really important to get them to a doctor or a hospital right away because those kinds of wounds can be very serious. While waiting for help, you can do a few things to help them feel better and keep them safe. First, you should stay calm and make sure the person is safe and not in any more danger. If the wound is bleeding a lot, you can gently press a clean cloth or bandage on it to help stop the bleeding. If the wound looks really bad or there are big pieces missing, it’s even more important to not touch it too much and let the doctors take care of it. Remember, it’s always best to let grown-ups handle serious things like this and get help right away!

title: We can manipulate an organism's DNA to emphasize several traits. What would it take to make a DNA from scratch, creating an entirely new organism?
text: Making a DNA from scratch to create a whole new living thing is like building a super complex Lego set without instructions. DNA is like a recipe that tells a living thing how to grow and work. To make DNA from scratch, scientists need to know the exact order of pieces, called nucleotides, that fit together perfectly. They have to figure out what parts are needed for things like skin color, how it eats, and how it moves. This is really hard because there are lots of tiny details, and even a small mistake can make the new organism very different or not work at all. Once they have the right pieces, they can put them together in a lab, and if everything goes well, they can put this new DNA into a cell. If the cell is happy with its new DNA, it can start to grow into a completely new organism! But it takes a lot of time, smart scientists, and special tools to do this.

title: Why is it illegal to pump your own gas in Oregon?
text: In Oregon, it's illegal to pump your own gas because the state wants to keep everyone safe and make sure things are done correctly. They have people called gas station attendants who are trained to handle the gas, so they can help make sure it doesn’t spill or cause accidents.
